book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram. Transcription and production supervised by Hamoud Al-Mutairi, may Allah grant him success and help those who aided him. In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Introduction. Praise be to Allah, the Lord of the worlds. We praise Him, seek His help, ask for His forgiveness, seek His guidance, and repent to Him. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides, no one can lead him astray, and whomever He leads astray, no one can guide him. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. O Allah, send prayers, peace, and blessings upon Your servant and Prophet Muhammad, and upon his family and all his companions. To proceed:

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The study of the Sunnah is among the most important, best, and most honorable of sciences in the sight of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted. One of the greatest means by which seekers draw near to Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, and for which they strive, is seeking the hadiths of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as well as caring for [distinguishing] the authentic from the weak among them. For the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is revelation (Wahy) from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, which He revealed to His Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) through Gabriel, and it is the peer of the Quran in terms of being authoritative proof. Therefore, Ahlus-Sunnah have agreed that the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is revelation from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted. Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said in His Great Book: {Nor does he speak from [his own] inclination. It is not but a revelation revealed} [An-Najm: 3-4]. This is a declaration from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, that the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is revelation from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. Based on this, the scholars and their methodology in their compilations have indicated this. Imam Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, dedicated the first book in his Sahih as: (The Book of the Beginning of Revelation), signaling that what follows in this book is revelation from Allah the Exalted to His Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Hence, pointing to this, he said in the Book of Monotheism (Tawheed) in his Sahih: (Chapter: The Mention of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and His Narration from His Lord). This is a point of agreement among scholars as well. Al-Darimi in his Sunan, Abu Dawud in Kitab al-Marasil, Al-Khatib in Al-Kifayah and Al-Faqih wal-Mutafaqqih, Ibn Abd al-Barr in his book Al-Jami', and Al-Marwazi in Kitab al-Sunnah narrated from Al-Awza'i from Hassan who said: 'Gabriel used to descend upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with the Sunnah just as he descended upon him with the Quran.'

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Al-Khatib narrated in his book Al-Kifayah from Ahmad bin Zaid bin Harun, who said: 'It is merely Salih [narrating] from Salih, Salih from a Tabi'i (Successor), a Tabi'i from a Sahib (Companion), a Sahib from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), the Messenger of Allah from Gabriel, and Gabriel from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic.' Meaning, this Sharia of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, comprising the Book and the Sunnah, is narrated until it reaches us: Salih from Salih, Salih from a Tabi'i, a Tabi'i from a Sahib, a Sahib from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Gabriel, and Gabriel from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. None of the revelation of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, stops at anyone among these besides Allah, the Glorified and Exalted. Whatever the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) says or does is entirely revelation from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. So, if the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was asked about something regarding the legislation of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, and he had prior revelation from Allah the Exalted, he would report it. But if he did not have revelation from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, he would then wait for the news from the heavens and would not speak on his own apart from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: There are reports from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding this that clarify the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) pausing and not speaking of his own accord. Among them is what the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated from the hadith of Isma'il from Ibn Jurayj from 'Ata from Safwan bin Umayyah from his father, that he used to say to Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him): 'I wish I could see the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when revelation descends upon him.' He said: So when the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was at Al-Ji'ranah, and there was a garment shading the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was with some of his companions, including Umar, a man came to him wearing a woolen cloak (jubbah) soaked in perfume. He said: 'O Messenger of Allah! What is your view regarding a man who enters Ihram for Umrah in a cloak after soaking himself in perfume?' He said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) looked at him for a while and then remained silent. Then the revelation came to him, and at that moment the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not have knowledge from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, or prior revelation [on this specific matter]. So Umar signaled with his hands to Ya'la bin Umayyah to come. Ya'la came and put his head in [under the covering], and behold, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was red-faced, wheezing for a while, then he was relieved of it. He said: «Where is the one who asked me about Umrah?» The man was sought and brought. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «As for the perfume that is on you, wash it three times, and as for the cloak, take it off, then do in your Umrah as you do in your Hajj.» This shows the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when that man who had entered Ihram for Umrah came to him—he came while the Prophet did not have knowledge about what he was wearing, for he had worn a sewn garment, which is the cloak, and soaked himself in perfume, both of which are prohibitions of Ihram. He asked the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about that, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not have prior revelation from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, so he waited for the revelation brought to him by Gabriel, peace be upon him. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) informed that his reports, statements, and rulings that he utters and performs, whether commands, prohibitions, actions, or abstentions and the like, are indeed revelation from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, and indeed they are from the Book of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. For Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, has linked obedience to His Prophet

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: - peace and blessings of Allah be upon him - to obedience to Him in several places in His Book, the Glorified and Exalted. Indeed, He informed that whoever disobeys the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) has indeed disobeyed Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. The two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated, saying: Qutaibah bin Sa'id told us, Laith told us, from Al-Zuhri from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah from Abu Hurairah and Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani, who said: A Bedouin came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, judge between us with the Book of Allah.' He said: His opponent, the other Bedouin, stood up and said: 'He spoke the truth, O Messenger of Allah, judge between us with the Book of Allah.' That Bedouin said: 'My son was a hired laborer for this man - meaning an employee shepherding his sheep - and he committed adultery with his wife. They told me that my son faces stoning. He said: So I ransomed my son from him with one hundred sheep and a maidservant. Then I asked the people of knowledge, and they said that my son faces one hundred lashes and banishment for a year.' The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «I will surely judge between you with the Book of Allah. As for the maidservant and the sheep, they are returned to you. And upon your son is one hundred lashes and banishment for a year. And as for you, O Unays, go to this man's wife in the morning, and if she confesses, stone her.» So Unays went to her, and she confessed, so he stoned her.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Whoever contemplates the rulings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) for this Bedouin and his opponent will find that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) issued rulings that are not in the Holy Quran textually, but rather they are from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from the revelation of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, which counts as the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that is the peer of the Holy Quran in terms of legal authority. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ruled regarding him that the sheep and the maidservant be returned to him because they were not the judgment of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted. He also ruled regarding his son one hundred lashes, and lashing is established in the Book of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, in Surah An-Nur in His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: {So lash each one of them with a hundred lashes}. Furthermore, he ruled regarding his son that he be lashed one hundred times and banished for a year, and banishment for a year is also not something explicitly stated in the Book of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, but rather it is from the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), even though the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «I will surely judge between you», and this is an oath from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «I will surely judge between you with the Book of Allah», yet he ruled that he be lashed one hundred times and banished for a year. This indicates that the rulings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) are the peer of the Book of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, which is the Holy Quran, in terms of legal authority.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) has informed in several places that his Sunnah and what comes from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of speech or action are the peer of the Book of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted; it is forbidden to reject them or turn away from them based on the saying of any person. Indeed, Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, informed in His Great Book that lack of reverence for the sayings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is a warning of the nullification of deeds. Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said in Surah Al-Hujurat: {O you who have believed, do not raise your voices above the voice of the Prophet or be loud to him in speech like the loudness of some of you to others, lest your deeds become worthless while you perceive not}. The nullification of deeds here does not arise from disbelief (Kufr) causing it, for it is known that disbelief in Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, nullifies deeds. However, here, those who raise their voices in the presence of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) may be people of faith who committed this sin, which perhaps indicates a lack of reverence for the sayings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Raising one's voice at the sayings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), whether during his life or after his death when hearing them from someone narrating them, carries the same ruling; it is a likely cause for the nullification of deeds, and refuge is sought with Allah, even if it is not disbelief. So what then is to be thought of one who prioritizes over the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), his methodology, and his guidance, the saying of another, their methodology, and their guidance? Has this person's deeds not become worthless without him realizing it..!! The two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated via Salih from Ibn Shihab who said, Urwah bin Al-Zubayr informed me from Aisha from her father, Al-Siddiq (Abu Bakr), that he said: 'I am not leaving anything that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to do except that I do it. Indeed, I fear that if I leave anything of his command, I will deviate.' This is Al-Siddiq fearing that if he left the Sunnah he would deviate, so what would be the case of a time and era whose people mock their Prophet and his commands and prohibitions, and compete in opposing him, and even ridicule his methodology.. Muslims have unanimously agreed that if a matter of the Sunnah becomes clear to someone, it is not lawful for him to leave it for the saying of anyone.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: If this is known, then the greatness of worshipping through caring for the Revelation and caring for what comes from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and worshipping based on it is known. And if it is known that the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is revelation from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, then the honor of that knowledge and its virtue with Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, is known. The righteous predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them, often cared for knowing the rulings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his states. Furthermore, the gatherings of Dhikr (remembrance) are actually gatherings of Halal and Haram; they are not gatherings of storytellers and the like. They are gatherings of Halal and Haram, knowing Fiqh (jurisprudence), knowing the rulings of the Quran and its interpretation, and so on. Abu Nu'aym narrated in his book Al-Hilyah from the hadith of Abu Abd al-Malik who said: Yazid bin Samra Abu Hazzan told us, saying: I heard 'Ata al-Khurasani say: 'Gatherings of Dhikr are gatherings of Halal and Haram.' Abu Nu'aym also narrated from the hadith of Yahya bin Kathir who said: 'Learning Fiqh is prayer, and studying the Quran is prayer.' Therefore, if it is known that the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is revelation from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, the honor of that knowledge and the greatness of the reward from Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, is known for the one who tracks the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), gains understanding of it, strives to memorize it and to distinguish its authentic from its weak, and defends it. This is among the highest ranks with Allah for the one granted sincerity and righteous intention. Yahya bin Yahya Al-Naysaburi said: 'Defending the Sunnah is better than Jihad in the path of Allah.' It was said to him: 'A man spends his wealth, tires himself, and strives (in Jihad), yet this is better than him?' He said: 'Yes, by far..' Abu Ubaid Al-Qasim bin Salam said: 'The follower of the Sunnah is like one holding onto burning coal, and he is, in my view today, better than striking with swords in the path of Allah.' This indicates the virtue of Jihad as much as it indicates the virtue of the Sunnah, as a preference was made between them due to their high status in Islam.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: We, in this lesson and the sessions that follow, are explaining a book that is among the greatest and most beneficial books in the chapter of Rulings (Ahkam), which is the book: (Bulugh al-Maram by Al-Hafiz Ahmad bin Ali bin Hajar Al-Asqalani, may Allah have mercy on him). His book Bulugh al-Maram is one of the most beneficial books of Rulings. He, may Allah have mercy on him, collected a group of hadiths of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from many books of Sunnah, some authentic and some less so; because he, may Allah have mercy on him, intended to gather what the followers of the schools of thought (Madhhabs) use as evidence for their opinions in the chapters of Fiqh. So he collected the hadiths and arranged them according to chapters, making it rare in its field; indeed, it is among the most precious books of Rulings authored by scholars among the later Imams, may Allah have mercy on them. The saying of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in his introduction: (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful....etc). The author, may Allah have mercy on him, in his book Bulugh al-Maram, began the introduction with the Basmalah. The phrase "Bismillah..." is called Basmalah for short, and one who says "Bismillah" is called Basmal or Mubasmit. Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah said: 'Layla said the Basmalah the morning I met her *** So how lovely is that beloved who says the Basmalah.' Al-Hafiz starting with the Basmalah is in emulation of the Mighty Book (Quran), and what was reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding mentioning the name of Allah (Tasmiyah) from his actions (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in many of his affairs such as correspondence and others. The command to say the Basmalah has been reported from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), but it is not established (authentic). Al-Khatib narrated in his Jami' from the hadith of Mubashir bin Isma'il from Al-Awza'i from Al-Zuhri from Abu Salamah from Abu Huraira raised (Marfu') [to the Prophet]: (Every matter of importance that does not begin with In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful, is cut off).

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: It is a munkar (denounced) report, essentially fabricated (mawdu'). It was deemed defective by Huffaz (Hadith Masters) like Imam Ahmad and Al-Daraqutni. The correct view regarding it is that it is Mursal (hurried/disconnected) and uses wording other than the Basmalah, and it is also Munkar. Mubashir bin Isma'il erred in it, narrating it with the wording of the Basmalah. A group such as Al-Walid bin Muslim, Baqiyyah, Kharijah bin Mus'ab, Shu'ayb bin Ishaq, Muhammad bin Kathir, Al-Mu'afa bin Imran, Abdul Quddus, and others narrated it from Al-Awza'i with the wording: (Every matter of importance that does not begin with 'Alhamdulillah' (Praise be to Allah)...), and the correct view regarding this wording is also Irsaal (disconnection). Those who attributed it with the Basmalah wording to the Sunan, like Al-Zayla'i, Al-Iraqi, Al-Suyuti, and others, were mistaken. Some late scholars were lenient and classified it as Hasan (Good), such as Al-Suyuti, who is very lenient in strengthening weak and flimsy reports, and he is imitated in this regard a lot. Therefore, the command for Basmalah in the previous report is not established. However, it is established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) through his action in correspondence. The two Sheikhs, Al-Bukhari and Muslim, narrated from the hadith of Al-Zuhri from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah from Abdullah bin Abbas from Abu Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with them, that he said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wrote to Heraclius: «In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. From Muhammad, the Messenger of Allah, to Heraclius, the Great of the Romans». This is established from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) through his action. Beginning with the Basmalah has been reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in several places, urging its commencement. Several situations have been reported from him regarding the encouragement of Tasmiyah (mentioning Allah's name) at the start of matters, whether starting actions, starting writing, or starting some acts of worship. Among them: Starting with the complete Basmalah (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful). This has been reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in several places: Among them is starting the recitation before Al-Fatihah after the opening Takbir with the Basmalah, as narrated by Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Ibn Hibban from Sa'id bin Abi Al-Hilal from Nu'aym Al-Mujmir: I prayed behind Abu Huraira and he recited: (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful...) the report, and in it Abu Huraira said: By Allah, I am the one among you whose prayer most resembles the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Similarly, beginning with it when reading [Quran] generally and when beginning writing, and there are authentic hadiths and narrations regarding that. * Also among the situations is starting one's action with the Basmalah by saying (Bismillah) without adding (Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim). This has been reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in situations, including what Imam Muslim narrated from the hadith of Al-Walid bin Kathir from Wahb bin Kaysan from Umar bin Abi Salamah that he ate with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: «Say Bismillah, and eat with your right hand.» Other texts mentioning the complete Tasmiyah have come regarding Tasmiyah at food. * Likewise, a third situation has been reported from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), which is the Tasmiyah without adding the phrase (Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim) but with the addition of something else. Among this is what was reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding placing the deceased in the grave, saying: «Bismillah wa 'ala millati Rasoolillah» (In the name of Allah and upon the religion of the Messenger of Allah), as narrated by Imam Ahmad, Abu Dawud, and others from the hadith of Shu'bah from Qatadah from Abu Al-Siddiq from Abdullah bin Umar. Also, what came in the Sahihayn (Bukhari and Muslim) from the hadith of Mansur from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd from Kurayb from Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «If one of you, when he comes to his wife [for intercourse], says: 'Bismillah, Allahumma jannibna al-shaytan wa jannib al-shaytan ma razaqtana' (In the name of Allah, O Allah, keep the devil away from us and keep the devil away from what You provide us)...» the report, as came from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). And a fourth situation is the wording of the report from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) coming with the phrase: (Dhikr of Allah / Mention of Allah) without specifying.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The Sunnah in this matter is to adhere to what the authentic hadiths have brought without adding to them. In situations where the report from him (peace and blessings be upon him) is established to say 'Bismillah Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim' completely, action and compliance with the Sunnah are not achieved except by mentioning it completely; if one limits oneself in those situations to 'Bismillah' only, compliance with the Sunnah is not achieved. In situations where limiting it to the phrase 'Bismillah' is established, compliance in those situations is adhering to saying 'Bismillah' only. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: One says 'Bismillah Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim' completely when eating, for it is more complete, unlike slaughtering. Regarding situations where the text establishes mentioning 'Bismillah' with an additional phrase other than 'Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim', compliance lies in saying 'Bismillah' with that addition. Whoever wants to add 'Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim' after 'Bismillah' and then mention the other addition established by text has not been compliant, because these are invocations and supplications where it is best to stop at what has been transmitted. As for situations where mentioning the name of Allah is established without specifying 'Bismillah Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim' or just 'Bismillah', one has the choice to mention the Basmalah completely, which is preferable, or to limit it to saying 'Bismillah'.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The scholars have agreed on the legitimacy of the Tasmiyah (saying Bismillah) as reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). However, scholars differed regarding starting poetry with the Basmalah. It has been narrated from some of the Salaf (predecessors) among the Tabi'in and others that Tasmiyah is disliked at the beginning of poetry and the like. Among this is what Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi narrated in Kitab Al-Jami' from the hadith of Junadah bin Salam, who is from the descendants of Jabir bin Samura, from Mujalid bin Sa'id from Al-Sha'bi, who said: 'They agreed not to write (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful) in front of poetry.' Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi also narrated it from another path from the hadith of Hafs bin Ghiyath from Mujalid from Al-Sha'bi, who said: 'They used to dislike writing (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful) in front of poems.' This opinion was also held by others besides Amir bin Sharahil Al-Sha'bi; it was also narrated from Al-Zuhri, may Allah have mercy on him, as Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi also narrated in his book Al-Jami' from the hadith of Abdul Aziz bin Imran Al-Zuhri from the son of Ibn Shihab's brother from his uncle who said: 'The Sunnah passed that (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful) is not written in poetry.' However, this opinion is not established from Amir bin Sharahil Al-Sha'bi because its chain contains Mujalid bin Sa'id, who is weak. The view held by the verifying scholars, and adopted by the generality of later scholars, is that beginning poetry—whether in a compilation or spoken—with the Basmalah is the Sunnah, and nothing excludes it from that unless established from the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This has been narrated from Sa'id bin Jubayr and others among the Tabi'in, as Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi narrated from the hadith of Muhammad bin Mus'ab from Jabalah bin Abi Sulayman who said: I heard Sa'id bin Jubayr say: 'No writing is proper unless its beginning is (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful), even if it is poetry.' This indicates the legitimacy of beginning with Tasmiyah in all actions and that this is the Sunnah, with nothing excepted from it, for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not except anything from that. Scholars have authored works on the Basmalah and its rulings, including Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr who has a section on it, and Ibn Al-Sabban who is among the later scholars.

text: The author, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, used certain terminologies in his book Bulugh al-Maram, which he stipulated in his introduction. He mentioned that if he says 'narrated by the Seven' (Al-Sab'ah), he means by that: the authors of the six books and Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on them. If he says 'narrated by the Four' (Al-Arba'ah), they are: the authors of the Sunan. And 'the Six' (Al-Sittah) are: Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and the authors of the four Sunan. Then he mentioned the rest of the terminologies he established, some of which are considered specific to him, may Allah have mercy on him. The terminologies of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in the book Bulugh al-Maram are terminologies a student of knowledge should know before beginning Bulugh al-Maram. Indeed, a student of knowledge should know the terminologies of scholars in their compilations so as not to fall into attributing error to scholars or faulting them without evidence. For every scholar has certain terminologies in his book, either mentioned in his introduction or learned by examination and observation of that book he authored, from which terminologies are extracted. For example, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, when saying: (Agreed upon / Muttafaq Alayh) here, means it was narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim, although there exist similar terminologies with some scholars meaning something other than just Al-Bukhari and Muslim as intended by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. For instance, the author of Al-Muntaqa, Al-Majd Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, if he says: (Agreed upon), he means it was narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Imam Ahmad.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Similarly, Abu Nu'aym Al-Asbahani, may Allah have mercy on him, in his book Hilyat al-Awliya, has some terminologies regarding this. If he uses the term (Agreed upon / Muttafaq Alayh), he does not mean in many cases that it was narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim, but rather he means that the conditions of authenticity were met in it. He used this phrase (Agreed upon) in his book Hilyat al-Awliya for hadiths that are not rare or few, yet I found they are not in Al-Bukhari or Muslim, may Allah have mercy on them, or are found in one of the Sahihs and not the other. This indicates he has a terminology different from what some scholars agreed upon and what the generality of later scholars adopted from them. For example, Al-Hafiz Abu Nu'aym, may Allah have mercy on him, cites some hadiths and says (Agreed upon) while they are not in Al-Bukhari and Muslim originally. Among them is what Abu Nu'aym narrated in his book Al-Hilyah from the hadith of Sufyan from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «The Imam is a guarantor, and the Muezzin is entrusted. O Allah, guide the Imams and forgive the Muezzins.» Abu Nu'aym, may Allah have mercy on him, said after narrating this report: Authentic, Agreed upon. This report is not in the two Sahihs nor in one of them. The author, may Allah have mercy on him, meant by this that the conditions of authenticity stipulated by scholars were met in it, and his intent is that this is the highest degree of authenticity according to him, may Allah have mercy on him. He said this phrase for more than one report, including what was also narrated via Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi from Sufyan from Abu Ishaq from Al-Bara', who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when returning from a journey, used to say: «Returning, repenting, to our Lord praising.» This is not in the two Sahihs nor in one of them. Rather, the author's intent, may Allah have mercy on him, in such places is that these hadiths have met the conditions of authenticity stipulated by scholars, intending that this is the highest degree of authenticity according to him, may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Therefore, a student of knowledge should know the terminologies of scholars in their works to be clear about their judgments and not to fall into error in understanding the intent of the Huffaz (Hadith Masters), may Allah have mercy on them. 1- On the authority of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding the sea: «Its water is purifying (Tahur), its dead are lawful (Halal).» Narrated by the Four, and Ibn Abi Shaybah, and the wording is his; authenticated by Ibn Khuzaymah and Al-Tirmidhi. The first hadith cited by the author, may Allah have mercy on him, is the hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, which scholars call the Hadith of the Sea. His saying, may Allah have mercy on him: (The Book of Purification / Kitab Al-Taharah): 'Kitab' (Book) comes from the root 'Kataba', meaning 'gathering'. It is said "The sons of so-and-so 'takattaba'" if they gathered together; a battalion (Katiba) is called so because of the gathering of its individuals with one another. Similarly, a book is called a book due to the gathering of its papers and their attachment to one another. Likewise, a written document (Maktub) is called so due to the gathering of letters in that document. Even if it is a single paper, it is called a Kitab (writing/letter) if something is written on it. The meaning of 'Kitab' here is gathering, as the poet said: Do not trust a Fazari (man from Fazarah) you are alone with... with your young she-camel, but tie it (uktub-ha) with straps. His saying, may Allah have mercy on him: (Purification / Al-Taharah): Purification in the Arabic language refers to: Cleanliness and integrity. 'The garment became Tahur from filth', meaning: it became clean and free from it. In the terminology of the Lawgiver, it applies to two meanings: First: Spiritual, which is the purification of the heart from Polytheism (Shirk) in the worship of Allah, and hatred for the believing servants of Allah. This is more important than bodily purification and more worthy of care, observation, and rectification. Second: Physical/Sensory, which is the lifting of ritual impurity (Hadath) and what is similar to it, and the removal of filth (Khabaath). His saying, may Allah have mercy on him: (Chapter on Waters / Bab Al-Miyah):

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The meaning of 'Bab' (Chapter/Door) here is: that from which one exits and enters, and this is known in the Arabic language. Scholars have agreed upon these nomenclatures: (Kitab/Book and Bab/Chapter). For the most part, scholars consider (Kitab) to be: that which gathers chapters of issues of knowledge or hadiths of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Among them is the author's saying, may Allah have mercy on him, (The Book of Purification); he intended by 'Book' here: The Collection, meaning a collector of hadiths of purification and reports that came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) or his companions, may Allah be pleased with them. By citing this report—the report of Abu Huraira, which is the first hadith in this chapter—the author, may Allah have mercy on him, intended to clarify the purifying nature of sea water, and that if sea water is pure/purifying, then other water is even more so. Scholars have made this report one of the fundamentals of purification in the Sharia. This report was narrated, as mentioned by the author, by Imam Ahmad and the authors of the Sunan. It was also narrated by Malik, Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim in Al-Mustadrak, and Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Sunan. It was also narrated by a group of scholars, all of them narrating it from the hadith of Safwan bin Sulaym from Sa'id bin Salamah from Al-Mughirah bin Abi Burdah that he heard Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, say: A man came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, we ride the sea and carry with us little water. If we perform ablution (Wudu) with it, we will become thirsty! Should we perform ablution with it [sea water]? The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «Its water is purifying (Tahur), its dead are lawful (Halal).»

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: This report has been accepted by the Ummah (Muslim community) with acceptance, and a group of scholars have authenticated it, such as Imam Al-Bukhari as in Al-Tirmidhi's Al-Ilal Al-Mufrad, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Khuzaymah, Al-Daraqutni who declared its chain good (Jayyid) as in his Ilal, as well as Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Abd al-Barr, Al-Hakim, Ibn Hibban, and other scholars. A group of scholars exceeding thirty Imams have authenticated it. I have not seen anyone among the scholars weaken this report except Ibn Daqiq al-Eid and Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi, for they found fault with it due to Sa'id bin Salamah and claimed his anonymity (Jahalah). Regarding Sa'id bin Salamah, Al-Nasa'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Reliable (Thiqah), and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in his book Al-Thiqat. However, the hadith of unknown narrators (Majahil) or those whose condition is hidden (Mastur) is not rejected absolutely by scholars; rather, consideration is given to their hadiths in some situations, and their hadiths are strengthened by certain indicators (Qara'in). Scholars accepted the hadith of Sa'id bin Salamah in this report because scholars received his report with acceptance, and it became widespread among them, so this served as an indicator for accepting the report. Scholars sometimes rely on the fame of the report instead of arguing via the chain of transmission, though this is in rare cases. Also, Huffaz (Hadith Masters) sometimes strengthen the hadiths of one who has no known criticism (Jarh) or commendation (Ta'dil) in some of what he narrates if indicators surround his truthfulness such that he does not bring something denounced (Munkar) nor brings eccentric wordings (Gharib). Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Hibban, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Al-Daraqutni have authenticated [narrations] for a group in whom no criticism or commendation was found, and that was after probing their hadith and finding it upright. This is not considered leniency from them, because their ignorance of the narrator's condition does not imply a defect that would make one fear strengthening him. Knowing the truthfulness, precision, and integrity of a narrator comes from probing and tracking his hadith, just as it comes from close association and testing. Leniency is only in strengthening the hadiths of the weak and authenticating the report of unknown narrators despite the eccentricity and denouncability of their hadith and their uniqueness in reporting it. Although the conditions of unknown narrators vary from one person to another, from one generation (Tabaqa) to another, and from one land to another, and also depending on those narrating from them. The unknown narrators among the early Tabi'in are not like those after them. One from whom Al-Sha'bi and Ibn Sirin narrated is not like one from whom

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: those with less memorization and verification narrated, even if their number is large, along with many indicators that the Huffaz employ in accepting the hadith of some unknown narrators. Therefore, you do not find the Imams and Huffaz having a single methodology they employ in accepting and rejecting the narrations of unknown narrators, as is not hidden. You find them authenticating the hadith and verifying the trustworthiness of someone known for only one hadith who is counted among the unknown due to the scarcity of his narration, while you find them rejecting someone who has more than two, three, four, or five hadiths. This is due to the varying indicators surrounding each one of them. For Aswad bin Sa'id, I know of no hadith for him other than (The transgressing party will kill Ammar), yet Yahya bin Ma'in and Ibn Hibban declared him reliable. Similarly, Harun bin Ri'ab, who has very few narrations; Sufyan bin Uyainah said: (He had four hadiths), yet Ahmad bin Hanbal, Yahya bin Ma'in, and Al-Nasa'i declared him reliable. Indeed, the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated from those who are among the 'hidden' (Masturin) and are not known by criticism or commendation, like Ibrahim bin Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Rabi'ah, for Al-Bukhari narrated from him and I do not know who declared him reliable. Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Awanah from Uthman bin Abdullah bin Mawhab from Ja'far bin Abi Thawr from Jabir bin Samura, who said that a man asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): Should I perform ablution from eating mutton? He said: If you wish perform ablution, and if you wish do not perform ablution. He said: Should I perform ablution from eating camel meat? He said: Yes, perform ablution from camel meat. And Ja'far bin Abi Thawr, I know of no one who declared him reliable except Ibn Hibban, yet Muslim narrated from him in his Sahih, and the Imams and Huffaz received his hadith with acceptance, to the point that Al-Hafiz Ibn Khuzaymah said in his Sahih: We have not seen disagreement among the scholars of the people of Hadith that this report is authentic from the perspective of transmission. In the two Sahihs, there is a not insignificant number of narrators who are counted among the 'hidden' (Masturin).
