text: Based on this, it is known that the matter of the unknown narrator (Majhul) varies according to what we mentioned. A narrator might be unknown to the Imams and Huffaz despite more than one person narrating from him, and he might be known to them—indeed, reliable and authentic in hadith—despite only one narrator reporting from him. Thus, the issue of the unknown narrator and lifting the state of anonymity is not dependent on the number of people narrating from him, as mentioned by many scholars of terminology and principles. The criticism by Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi and Ibn Daqiq of the Sea Water hadith due to the anonymity of its narrator is questionable. Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi is among those who are very strict in this chapter and applies taking the apparent state of the chains, and he rarely utilizes indicators (Qara'in), similar to the state of a group of scholars like Ibn Hazm, Al-Khatib, and many of the later scholars. The purity of sea water is something on which there is no disagreement among scholars, except for a minor opinion narrated from some Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His saying here at the beginning of the report: (We ride the sea) contains evidence for the permissibility of riding the sea, and that the default rule regarding it is permissibility. This is what the Book of Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, indicates, for Allah the Exalted mentioned riding the ark and riding the sea in several places in His Book, the Glorified and Exalted. Allah the Exalted said: {It is He who enables you to travel on land and sea}. Travel is: riding a beast on land, as well as walking on feet, and travel in the sea means: riding arks and ships. Also His saying, the Glorified and Exalted: {And the ships which sail through the sea with that which benefits people}.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: As for the case where there is a prevalent belief of destruction, such as waves and the like, then it becomes forbidden. Therefore, some reports have been narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) which are weak. Among them is what Sa'id narrated, and from Sa'id Abu Dawud and Al-Bayhaqi, from the hadith of Mutarrif bin Tarif from Bishr Abu Abdullah from Bashir bin Muslim from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «Let no man ride the sea except a fighter (Ghazian), or a pilgrim performing Umrah or Hajj, for indeed under the sea is fire and under the fire is a sea.» This report has been weakened by some scholars; it is disturbed (Mudtarib) and weak in chain, denounced in text. Imam Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, weakened it as in his Tarikh, and Ibn Abd al-Barr said: Its chain is dark. What was narrated regarding prohibition from some of the Salaf regarding riding the sea is interpreted to apply to the case of believing destruction is likely due to intensifying waves and intensifying wind and the like; then it is prohibited and becomes unlawful. For this reason, Al-Shafi'i hesitated in obligating Hajj on those beyond the sea; he said, may Allah have mercy on him: It is not clear to me that I should obligate Hajj on those beyond the sea, nor do I know how their capability stands. This has been narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, as Abdul-Razzaq narrated in his Musannaf from the hadith of Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib who said: (Umar used to dislike transporting Muslims as fighters by sea). This is authentic from Umar, even if Ibn Al-Musayyib did not hear from Umar, it is taken as connected. The generality of early Huffaz authenticated his hadith from Umar, and I know of no opponent in that except Al-Tirmidhi who authenticates it in some places and faults it in others. Among those who explicitly authenticated it are Imam Ahmad, Abu Hatim, Ibn Al-Madini, and others. This narration applies to the state of severe waves and severe wind and prevalence of thought of destruction, then it becomes disliked, indeed forbidden. Umar permitted it in other than that state, as Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Nafi' from Ibn Umar that Tamim Al-Dari asked Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, about riding the sea—and he was a great merchant in the sea—so he ordered him to shorten the prayer. Among that also is what was narrated from Abdullah bin Umar as Abdul-Razzaq narrated from the hadith of Laith from

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Mujahid from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with him (that he used to dislike riding the sea except for three: a fighter, a pilgrim performing Hajj, or Umrah). This report is not established from Abdullah bin Umar; its chain contains Laith bin Abi Sulaym who is weak by agreement of the Huffaz, may Allah have mercy on them. His hadiths from Mujahid are considered weak except for his hadith from Mujahid from Abdullah bin Abbas in Tafsir (Exegesis), for that may pass because it is from a book, as mentioned by Ibn Hibban, may Allah have mercy on him, for he narrates it from the hadith of Laith bin Abi Sulaym, and Laith narrates it from Al-Qasim bin Abi Bazzah from Mujahid bin Jabr from Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him. The rest of Laith bin Abi Sulaym's hadiths from Mujahid bin Jabr and others are considered weak by scholars. However, Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, in the issue of riding the sea, distinguished between men and women. It was narrated from him that he disliked a woman riding in the sea absolutely; interpreting that as a woman, if she rides a ship, would then need to uncover her Awrah (intimate parts) for relieving herself and the like, so she would be exposed. This is overlooked for a man but not forgiven for a woman. Also, in riding a ship, she might see the Awrah of men, and see the bodies of men on ships because riding ships requires hardship and toil which necessitates exposing the chest, belly, and back, as well as needing to uncover the Awrah out of necessity. This is what Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, used as evidence to prevent women and dislike riding the sea for them. However, this is mostly negated, especially in our time, so the woman remains on the original ruling of the permissibility of riding the sea for her. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Its water is purifying (Tahur)»:

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: (Tahur): If it comes with a Fatha (Ta-hur), the meaning is the water itself, which purifies the one purifying himself with it. If it comes with a Damma (Tu-hur), the meaning is the act of purifying. Similarly: Wudu (ablution) and Ghusl (bathing); if it comes with a Damma, the meaning is the state/act of bathing and the act of ablution and the state of purification. If it comes with a Fatha, the meaning is that with which one bathes, purifies, and performs ablution. Al-Nawawi narrated this from the majority. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Its water is purifying (Tahur)»: This, as we mentioned, is a point of consensus among scholars, except for a slight disagreement narrated from some Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). However, it is not considered against what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The purifying nature of sea water has been narrated from a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and they stated it explicitly. Among them is Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, as Abu Bakr Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated in his Musannaf from the hadith of Ubaidullah bin Umar from Amr bin Dinar from Abu Al-Tufayl who said: Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq was asked: Can one perform ablution with sea water? He said: (Its water is purifying, its dead are lawful). This was also narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, Ibn Abbas, Ibn Sirin, Al-Hasan, Ikrimah, Tawus, and Ata. Some scholars held that sea water is pure, but they deemed fresh water better than it, and that one should not resort to purifying oneself with sea water except when fresh water is lacking. This is narrated from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, and also from Al-Nakha'i, as Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated from the hadith of Shu'bah from Qatadah from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib who said: (If you are forced to it, there is no harm), meaning if you are forced to purify with sea water, there is no harm, implying he sees purification with water that is not salty but fresh [as preferable]. Similarly, it was narrated from Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i as Ibn Abi Shaybah and Abdul-Razzaq narrated in their Musannafs from Sufyan from Al-Zubayr bin Adi from Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i who said: (Sea water suffices, but fresh water is more beloved to me than it). However, what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) indicates equality between fresh water and sea water.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The saying of Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib and Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i does not stand against what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). As mentioned, some scholars from the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), who are few, held the view of the non-purity of sea water and the lack of legitimacy in performing ablution with it. Among them: Abdullah bin Umar and Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them. Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated from the hadith of Shu'bah from Qatadah from Uqbah, who said: I heard Abdullah bin Umar say: (Tayammum [dry ablution] is more beloved to me than ablution from sea water). So Abdullah bin Umar turned to Tayammum, which is a substitute, and that only happens when water is missing.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: It is known that whoever performs Tayammum while water exists and he is capable and able to use it, his purification is considered invalid and his prayer is considered invalid by consensus, except for an excuse that compels him to Tayammum such as illness, cold, and the like. But if he is not excused, then his Tayammum is considered invalid and his purification invalid, and he must perform ablution with water. So when Abdullah bin Umar turned to Tayammum and left purifying with sea water, it was understood that he did not view sea water as purifying. However, this does not stand against what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Likewise is what was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with him, as Ibn Abi Shaybah and Al-Bayhaqi narrated from the hadith of Hisham from Qatadah from Abu Ayyub from Abdullah bin Amr who said: (Sea water does not suffice for ablution nor Janabah [major ritual impurity]; indeed under the sea is fire, then water, then fire). This statement from Abdullah bin Amr, like that from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, shows they do not see sufficiency in sea water. This does not stand against what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This was also narrated from Abu Huraira in the Musannaf of Ibn Abi Shaybah but it is not authentic. And from Abu Al-Aliyah Al-Riyahi, who is Rufai' bin Mihran, as Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated from the hadith of Abu Ja'far from Al-Rabi' bin Anas from Abu Al-Aliyah that he rode the sea and his water ran out, so he performed ablution with Nabidh (date-water) and disliked performing ablution with sea water. He is among the major Tabi'in, may Allah have mercy on him. This is not established due to the condition of its chain. Therefore, sea water is purifying, and the disagreement regarding it is not considered. The consensus of scholars on the purifying nature of sea water has been recounted by a group of scholars, including Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr, may Allah have mercy on him, and others. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Its dead are lawful (Halal)»:

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Meaning 'Halal' (lawful), as came in some narrations by Al-Daraqutni, may Allah have mercy on him, and other scholars, though there is debate on the soundness of the wording. The dead animals of the sea are Halal by consensus of scholars, except that scholars differed in excepting some dead animals of the sea. Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The dead animals of the sea are Halal except what is in the form of an animal like a dog or the form of a human and the like. Imam Ahmad, and this is the well-known position from him, may Allah have mercy on him, held: That the dead animals of the sea are Halal except the snake, the frog, and the crocodile. He said that the snake and the frog are among the foul things (Khaba'ith) and that the crocodile is considered among those about whom the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: It possesses a fang, and he forbade it. What the majority of scholars hold is that the dead animals of the sea are all considered permissible and Halal by the text of the Prophet's saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). As for what Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, excepted regarding what was in the form of an animal and the like, there is no evidence for it, and it does not stand against what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) generalized permissibility regarding sea dead. As for what came from Imam Ahmad regarding excepting the frog and the crocodile, the frog is not considered a dead animal of the sea as it does not stay in the sea always, nor does it stay in the land, for it is between them; so it is not considered a sea dead animal, nor is it considered a land animal. Similar is the crocodile, for it lives between land and sea. The generalization of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intended the dead of the sea, meaning if the animal is taken out of the sea, it dies. Thus, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) generalized permissibility for sea dead absolutely without exception. Whatever is known to be harmful among sea dead is then forbidden due to its harm, for there is no harm or reciprocating harm in Islam. Nothing is excepted from sea dead except what is proven harmful. As for what is between land and sea among animals, it is not considered a sea animal and remains on the original principle of permissibility. If it is among the foul things, it is considered foul. Whatever is likewise among harmful animals, it is then forbidden due to its harm, so there is no

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: harm or reciprocating harm in Islam. Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, has forbidden in His Great Book eating foul things. Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, said: {And makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil}. *************************************** 2- On the authority of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «Indeed, water is purifying (Tahur), nothing makes it impure.» Narrated by the Three, and authenticated by Ahmad. The hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, was cited by the author, may Allah have mercy on him, stating that the Three narrated it. This is a terminology specific to him, may Allah have mercy on him. As for 'the Three' here, meant by them are: Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Nasa'i; they are the people of the Sunan excluding Ibn Majah, may Allah have mercy on them all. This is among the terminologies considered specific to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in his book Bulugh al-Maram. Therefore, we said that a student of knowledge should pay attention to the terminologies of scholars in their compilations to be clear about their judgments. This hadith was narrated by Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Nasa'i. It was also narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, and Ibn Khuzaymah, all of them from the path of Hammad bin Usamah (Abu Usamah) from Al-Walid bin Kathir from Muhammad bin Ka'b from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: This hadith was authenticated by Imam Ahmad as mentioned by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him. It was also authenticated by Ibn Ma'in, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him. Imam Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him, classified it as Hasan (Good). He said after narrating it in his Sunan: This is a Hasan hadith, and Abu Usamah has presented this hadith excellently. When Imam Al-Tirmidhi uses the term (Hasan) on a hadith solely without addition, he usually implies weakness, but here he added [praise] and did not isolate it; and this is mostly the case, for he has called a few hadiths narrated in the Sahihayn just (Hasan). Ibn Al-Jawzi, may Allah have mercy on him, quoted in his book Al-Tahqiq from Imam Al-Daraqutni saying: That this hadith is not established. But Al-Daraqutni's speech, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding this report does not refer to this hadith from this path. Ibn Al-Jawzi's transmission, may Allah have mercy on him, from Imam Al-Daraqutni applying this speech to this path contains some laxity and leniency and is closer to illusion than intent; otherwise, Al-Daraqutni's speech, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding this hadith does not intend this path, may Allah have mercy on him. This hadith was deemed defective due to the anonymity of Ubaidullah bin Abdullah—and it was said Ubaidullah bin Abdur-Rahman. Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi, may Allah have mercy on him, faulted it due to his anonymity, weakening the report by the anonymity of Ubaidullah bin Abdullah or Ibn Abdur-Rahman. He said, may Allah have mercy on him—i.e., Ibn Al-Qattan—in his book (Al-Wahm wal-Iham): Whatever the case, he is one whose condition and identity are unknown. Ibn Mandah, may Allah have mercy on him, said about him that he is unknown (Majhul). Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, said: regarding the one who named his father Abdur-Rahman, he said: that is an error (Wahm). The meaning of this hadith is narrated from a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. It was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, Abu Huraira, Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, and Ibn Abbas. It is also narrated from a group of Tabi'in such as Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, Mujahid bin Jabr, and Ikrimah the freedman of Abdullah bin Abbas. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Indeed, water is purifying (Tahur)»:

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: (Tahur): Here, if it has a Fatha, the meaning is the water with which purification is performed. Similar is Wudu and Ghusl. But if it comes with a Damma, the meaning is the action; so if he says: Tuhur, Ghusl, or Wudu [with Damma], the meaning is the action, the action of the one performing ablution, bathing, or purifying. This is according to the majority of scholars, as transmitted by Imam Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, and a group. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Indeed, water is purifying (Tahur), nothing makes it impure». This is the basic principle regarding water: that it remains on its purity. Allah, the Glorified and Exalted, sent it down pure, so it does not transfer from its original state except with clear evidence, or a text from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). If this water's attributes are changed by impurity, it is impure (Najis). Or by experience and testing if it is known that such water is impure; then in that case, it has transferred from its original state to impurity. So the origin in water is purity, and this is general as the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said here: «Indeed, water is purifying, nothing makes it impure». His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Nothing makes it impure»: It is absolute but restricted by other reports, that if some impurity mixes with it and changes one of its three attributes, it has become impure by consensus. The explanation of this will come, by the permission of Allah the Exalted, in the hadith of Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, which follows. *************************************** 3- On the authority of Abu Umamah Al-Bahili, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «Indeed, water is not made impure by anything, except what overcomes its smell, its taste, and its color.» Narrated by Ibn Majah, and weakened by Abu Hatim. This hadith was narrated by Ibn Majah, and it was also weakened by Abu Hatim. Ibn Majah, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated it from the hadith of Rishdin bin Sa'd from Mu'awiyah bin Salih from Rashid bin Sa'd from Abu Umamah Al-Bahili, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The Muhaddithun (Hadith scholars) have agreed on the weakness of this hadith and impugning it. Its chain contains Rishdin bin Sa'd, whom a group of scholars have weakened. Imam Ahmad, Abu Zur'ah, and Al-Nasa'i weakened him. Abu Dawud and Yahya bin Ma'in said: He is nothing. Imam Ahmad also said: There is no harm in him regarding Al-Raqa'iq (heart-softening narrations). Abu Hatim said: His hadith is Munkar (denounced). The correct view regarding this report is that it is Mursal (hurried/disconnected) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and is not authentic as connected (Mawsul) to him, as narrated by Abdul-Razzaq and Al-Daraqutni from the hadith of Al-Ahwas bin Hakim from Rashid bin Sa'd as Mursal from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This is the correct view preferred by a group of Huffaz like Abu Hatim Al-Razi and Imam Al-Daraqutni, may Allah have mercy on them. Al-Daraqutni said: No one raised it (connected it to the Prophet) other than Rishdin from Mu'awiyah, and he is not strong. Thawr bin Yazid followed Rishdin [in narrating], as narrated by Al-Bayhaqi from the hadith of Atiyyah bin Baqiyyah from his father from Thawr with it, and it is flimsy (Wahin). There is much disagreement in it; sometimes it is made from the Musnad of Abu Umamah and sometimes from Thawban. Scholars have agreed on the weakness of this hadith, and the consensus was recounted by a group like Imam Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him. However, its meaning is correct, and scholars have acted upon it. Indeed, a group of scholars recounted consensus on the correctness of its meaning, as recounted by Imam Ibn Hibban, may Allah have mercy on him, in his Sahih. Thus, the principle is that water is pure and purifying; it does not transfer from its original state except by an impurity that occurs in it changing one of its attributes. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «Except what overcomes its smell, its taste, and its color»: Scholars have agreed that there is no difference between the change of water by any of these three attributes—whether smell, taste, or color—and that this is a sign of the water's impurity if it has been changed by impurity. The only exception is a strange (Shadh) opinion narrated from Ibn Majashun, may Allah have mercy on him, excepting smell, but this has no weight against the consensus of scholars. The consensus was recounted by Al-Shafi'i, Ibn Al-Mundhir, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Abd al-Barr, Ibn Qudamah, and Ibn Taymiyyah.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: The majority of scholars divide water into three categories. This is the view of the Hanbalis, Shafi'is, Malikis, and Hanafis: that water is divided into three categories: Tahur (Purifying), Tahir (Pure but not purifying), and Najis (Impure). They used as evidence the Hadith of the Sea, arguing that the questioner knew sea water was not Najis, but wanted to know if it was Tahir or Tahur. They also used hadiths forbidding bathing in stagnant water and washing the hand after sleep before dipping it. The explanation of these reports and their meanings will come. Some scholars held—which is a narration from Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, reported from Abu Hanifa, and held by a group of verifying scholars like Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah—that water is of two categories: Tahir (Pure/Purifying) and Najis (Impure). They used the hadith of Bi'r Buda'ah (Well of Buda'ah) and others as evidence. The verified view upon gathering evidences becomes clear: Water is divided into two categories: Tahir (Pure/Purifying) and Najis (Impure), and what scholars named 'Tahur' falls under the category of 'Tahir'. If water is changed by impurity that mixed with it and one of its attributes changed, then in that case it is considered Najis. This is the school of the four Imams; indeed, consensus has been recounted on this. And if water is changed in one of its attributes by the proximity (Mujawarah) of impurity to it, not by mixing; then it is considered Najis as well, and consensus has been recounted on this. So if one of the attributes of water changes by mixing or proximity, then that water is considered Najis. Consensus on this has been recounted by a group of scholars like Imam Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him. If water is changed by something pure (Tahir), like Nabidh (date-water/juice) and the like, is it considered Tahir (pure/purifying) or not? Scholars differed on this: - Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, held that one may perform ablution with it in one case: if he finds nothing else, then he performs ablution with it. Some Hanafis held—a view of Muhammad bin Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him—that it is Tahir Mutahhir (Pure and Purifying), but one performs Tayammum along with it as a precaution. This view contains some contradiction [to Sunnah], for it has not been reported from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in any situation that a man combines Wudu and Tayammum, and this implies some hardship.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: - The Malikis, Shafi'is, and Hanbalis—which is the view of the majority of scholars—held that one performs Tayammum and does not perform ablution with it. This is narrated from a group, just as it is narrated from Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, and also from Imam Ibn Hazm. They said this liquid is not called water except with an addendum (e.g., rose water, date water). They said consensus has formed that lifting ritual impurity (Hadath) is only by pure water. They said: Imam Ibn Al-Mundhir, may Allah have mercy on him, recounted that Hadath is not lifted by any liquid except water, and this [Nabidh] has been mixed with something else changing its color while remaining pure, but it does not lift Hadath. - Those who permitted ablution with Nabidh relied on what Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated: Yahya bin Zakariya told us from Isra'il from Abu Fazarah from Abu Zaid, freedman of Amr bin Hurayth, from Ibn Masud who said: I was with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) the night he met the Jinn. He said: «Do you have water?» I said: No. He said: «What is in this vessel?» I said: Nabidh. He said: «Show it to me.» The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «A good date and purifying water.» So he performed ablution from it and then prayed. However, this hadith is weak and not authentic. Its chain contains Abu Zaid, who is counted among the unknown narrators (Majahil). Imam Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him, said about him: Abu Zaid is a man unknown to the scholars of Hadith; he is not known to have any narration other than this hadith. Similarly, Al-Bukhari, Al-Hakim, and Ibn Adi declared his anonymity. He is the narrator from Abdullah bin Masud in this report. Thus, it is not valid to use it as evidence. For this reason, Al-Hafiz Ibn Adi, may Allah have mercy on him, faulted it saying: This hadith revolves around Abu Fazarah from Abu Zaid, freedman of Amr bin Hurayth, from Ibn Masud. Abu Fazarah is well-known, his name is Rashid bin Kaysan. Abu Zaid, freedman of Amr bin Hurayth, is unknown. This hadith is not authentic from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and it contradicts the Quran.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: It contains a contradiction [to the principle] that if water's attributes change: if by impurity, it becomes impure; and if by a pure substance, it remains pure [in itself], but it does not lift ritual impurity (Hadath). If it touches a person's body or clothes, it is not counted as impure; rather, it is among pure substances, but it does not lift Hadath for worship. *************************************** 4- And for Al-Bayhaqi: «Water is pure (Tahir) unless its smell, taste, or color changes; by an impurity that occurs in it.» This was narrated by Al-Bayhaqi, may Allah have mercy on him, from the path of Atiyyah bin Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid from his father from Thawr from Rashid bin Sa'd from Abu Umamah. Atiyyah bin Baqiyyah is considered truthful (Saduq), as narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from his father in Al-Jarh wal-Ta'dil. However, his father Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid is among the Mudallisin (those who hide defects in the chain), and the coming of this report from this path contains some denouncability (Nakara) and strangeness (Gharabah). Thus, this path is not authentic from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and discussion on it has preceded. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «By an impurity that occurs in it»: This was used as evidence by those who said water does not become impure by proximity (Mujawarah). We mentioned that this opinion is strange (Shadh), attributed to Ibn Majashun. Rather, if one of the water's attributes changes by mixing or proximity, it is considered impure and it is not permissible to purify with it, for it lifts neither ritual impurity (Hadath) nor physical impurity (Najas). *************************************** 5- On the authority of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «If water reaches two Qullahs (jars), it does not carry filth.» And in a wording: «It does not become impure.» Narrated by the Four, and authenticated by Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban. This hadith is what scholars call the Hadith of the Two Qullahs. It is narrated from the hadith of Hammad bin Usamah from Al-Walid bin Kathir from Muhammad bin Abbad bin Ja'far from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah from his father Abdullah bin Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: This report has been faulted by some scholars, and authenticated by a group who are the majority. It was faulted due to disturbance (Idtirab) in its chain. It was narrated from Al-Walid bin Kathir from Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr instead of Muhammad bin Abbad bin Ja'far. In some paths, it was narrated as Abdullah bin Abdullah instead of Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with them. Scholars differed in preferring these aspects. Abu Dawud Al-Sijistani in his Sunan preferred the narration of Muhammad bin Abbad bin Ja'far. A group of Huffaz like Ibn Mandah, Ibn Hibban, and Abu Hatim disagreed with him, preferring the narration of Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr. A group of Huffaz like Imam Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Daraqutni, and also Al-Zayla'i preferred both aspects [as valid]. Some scholars weakened it. Ibn Al-Qayyim and Ibn Daqiq al-Eid weakened it. Abu Bakr Ibn Al-Arabi weakened it while critiquing Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, in his book (Ahkam Al-Quran), as well as in his explanation of Sunan Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him. But he was odd when he faulted it due to Al-Walid bin Kathir. For Al-Walid bin Kathir is a reliable Hafiz (Thiqah Hafiz); the Group (authors of the six books) narrated from him, and no scholar impugned him except Ibn Sa'd, may Allah have mercy on him, who said: "He is not that [strong]." But Al-Walid bin Kathir is among the well-known reliable narrators from whom the Group narrated, and Ibn Sa'd's criticism of him, may Allah have mercy on him, is not accepted against the words of the Huffaz, may Allah have mercy on them. This report was also authenticated by a group of scholars: Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim. Its authentication is also narrated from Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi, and among the later scholars Ibn Taymiyyah and others, may Allah have mercy on them.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: A group of scholars have authored works discussing it and its paths. Al-Ala'i, may Allah have mercy on him, authored a section collecting the paths of this report. Muhammad bin Abdul Wahid Al-Maqdisi also authored a section collecting its paths, refuting Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr, may Allah have mercy on him, regarding his weakening of this report, for Ibn Abd al-Barr, may Allah have mercy on him, weakened this report and was severe in weakening it; so Al-Maqdisi, may Allah have mercy on him, critiqued him in a section of his. It was also faulted due to disturbance in its text, as doubt was narrated in some paths: it appeared in some paths as 'two Qullahs or three' and did not say 'two Qullahs' only. This is narrated from the hadith of Hammad bin Usamah from Asim bin Al-Mundhir from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah from Abdullah bin Umar. Hammad bin Usamah changed at the end [of his life], and he opposed the reliable narrators in his narration here, falling into doubt. His saying here is outweighed due to his opposition to the reliable narrators, and this doubt counts as Shadh (an anomaly). Al-Hafiz Al-Bayhaqi, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified this and showed that this narration is outweighed. Also, among what occurred in it is that in some narrations it came that these Qullahs are 'Qullahs of Hajar', as Ibn Adi narrated in his Kamil from the hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Saqlab from Muhammad bin Ishaq from Nafi' from Abdullah bin Umar. Al-Mughirah bin Saqlab is 'Munkar al-Hadith' (his hadith is denounced). Al-Daraqutni, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified that this path is an error (Wahm) as he clarified in his Ilal, and he showed that the correct version is from Muhammad bin Ishaq from Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah from Abdullah bin Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with them.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: Regardless of the discussion on its paths, a group has authenticated this report and others have weakened it. Some said that faulting it due to disturbance (Idtirab), whether in text or chain, does not weaken it; rather, the textual disturbance indicates the weakness of those specific aspects, while the origin of the hadith is established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). As for the chain disturbance, some scholars have answered it with answers, and some preferred both aspects, saying it was narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in these two ways, as is the saying of Imam Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Zayla'i, may Allah have mercy on them. Ibn Al-Qayyim expanded greatly in weakening this report and refuting those who strengthened it with valuable, solid, and strong speech. (Al-Qullah) is: with a Damma on the Qaf, taken from height/elevation. It is said: 'Qullat al-Jabal' meaning its peak. Scholars differed regarding the volume of the Qullah in the report of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the measure by which the Qullah is known, according to several opinions: - It was narrated that the meaning of Qullah is two skins (Qirbah). This appeared in Kitab Al-Umm by Al-Shafi'i. He, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated in his book Al-Umm and also in his Musnad, saying: Muslim bin Khalid told us from Ibn Jurayj who said: The Qullahs of Hajar are two skins or two skins and a bit. - There is another opinion, the second opinion on the volume of the Qullah, narrated from Imam Al-Shafi'i, Imam Ahmad, and Abu Thawr, may Allah have mercy on them. They said: The Qullah holds two and a half skins. They used as evidence what was narrated from Ibn Jurayj previously, saying that Ibn Jurayj's saying 'The Qullah holds two skins or two skins and a bit', his saying (a bit / shay'an) here: the term 'shay'' is most often applied to a portion or a half. They said: So it is said as a precaution that the Qullah holds two and a half skins. This, as mentioned, is narrated from Imam Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Abu Thawr. - There is a third opinion: They said the Qullah holds six skins. This is narrated from Ishaq bin Rahwayh, may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: - There is a fourth opinion on the volume of the Qullah: That it holds two Faraq (a specific measure). This is narrated from Yahya bin Aqil as Al-Daraqutni narrated in his Sunan, may Allah have mercy on him, from the hadith of Ibn Jurayj from Muhammad bin Yahya from Yahya bin Aqil who said: I saw the Qullahs of Hajar, and I saw the Qullah holds two Faraq. - A fifth opinion was also narrated regarding this: They said that the Qullah does not have a specific known volume from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This is narrated from Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi, and also narrated from Waki', Yahya bin Adam, and a group of scholars. It is also narrated from Abu Ubaid, may Allah have mercy on them. The true opinion regarding this, by the permission of Allah the Exalted, is that the Two Qullahs do not have a specific volume according to scholars; but the meaning of Qullah is the Qullahs of Hajar, as recounted by some scholars. The Qullahs of Hajar were known among the Arabs, and their fame reached Medina. Indeed, they appeared on the tongue of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in an authentic report, as in the story of Isra' and Mi'raj from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as came in the Sahih from the hadith of Qatadah from Anas from Malik bin Sa'sa'ah, may Allah be pleased with him, in a long report. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «Then I was raised to the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary (Sidrat al-Muntaha), and I saw its fruits (Nabq) like the Qullahs of Hajar.» This indicates that the Qullahs of Hajar were known among the Arabs and known on the tongue of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and they are the closest to what the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intended. The Qullah, as we mentioned, upon verification for one who contemplates the reports of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), refers to the Qullahs of Hajar. If it is also known that the Qullahs of Hajar do not have a specific volume, it is known that the intent of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in this report is prevalence of thought (Ghalabat al-Zann), not certainty. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «If water reaches two Qullahs, it does not carry filth»: The saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), if authentic: «If water reaches two Qullahs, it does not carry filth», has an explicit meaning (Mantuq) and an implied meaning (Mafhum).

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: * Its explicit meaning: If water is two Qullahs—despite the difference in the volume of the two Qullahs—it does not carry filth, unless its taste, smell, or color changes due to impurity occurring in it. This is a point of consensus among scholars. * The implied meaning of this report: Whatever is less than two Qullahs, the prevailing thought is that impurity affects it. However, scholars differed on the implied meaning here: Does what is less than two Qullahs become impure upon meeting impurity, even if its smell, taste, or color does not change? There is disagreement among scholars. - The Hanafis, Shafi'is, and an opinion among the Hanbalis (a narration from Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him) held: That if impurity meets small water, it becomes impure, even if its smell, taste, or color does not change. But those who held this view—which is the majority view—differed regarding 'small water': - The Hanafis said: Small water is that which if one side is moved, the other side moves. - The Hanbalis and Shafi'is held that small water is: Whatever is less than two Qullahs as estimated by the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). - A group of scholars held the second view, which is the saying of Ibn Al-Musayyib, Al-Hasan, Al-Thawri, Imam Malik may Allah have mercy on him, Ibn Mahdi, a narration from Ahmad, and it is the view of the verifying scholars like Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah: That if impurity meets water and it is small, even if less than two Qullahs, it does not become impure unless its smell, color, or taste changes from that impurity. This is the true opinion. For the implied meaning of this report, if authentic from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), is contradicted by the explicit meaning from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the previous reports: «Indeed, water is purifying, nothing makes it impure». This is general speech from which nothing, small or large, is excepted.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: So the report of the Two Qullahs here is taken to mean that if water is abundant—two Qullahs or more—the probability of impurity occurring in it decreases, and if it is less than two Qullahs, then the prevailing thought is the occurrence and dominance of impurity over it, necessitating that criterion: that its smell, color, or taste changes from that impurity occurring in it. *************************************** 6- On the authority of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: «None of you should bathe in stagnant water while he is Junub (sexually impure).» Narrated by Muslim. And for Al-Bukhari: «None of you should urinate in stagnant water that does not flow, then bathe in it.» And for Muslim: «from it» (Minhu). And for Abu Dawud: «And nor bathe in it from Janabah.» This hadith was narrated by Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Harun told us, Ibn Wahb told us, Amr bin Al-Harith informed me from Bukayr bin Al-Ashaj from Abu Al-Sa'ib, freedman of Hisham bin Zuhrah, from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «None of you should bathe»: The 'Lam' (La) here is the Lam of prohibition (Nahiyah). Scholars differed on the implication of that prohibition: Is it for Haram (unlawfulness) or not? - The Malikis went and said that the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): «None of you should bathe in stagnant water that does not flow, then bathe in it»—despite the difference in narrations in Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawud, may Allah have mercy on them—they said: This is interpreted as Makruh (disliked), specifically Karahat al-Tanzih (dislike of purity/propriety). They reasoned saying: The water remains on its purity and is not impure. So, this indicates that the prohibition here is a prohibition of dislike, not unlawfulness, for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) does not prohibit something when the end result is the purity of the water even if the servant does it.

book_title: A Fragment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested People
text: - The Hanbalis and the opinion of the Zahiris went to the view that the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) here is for Haram (unlawfulness). They reasoned with many causes; they said: The default in the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is unlawfulness, and this is not diverted except for an obvious cause or an obvious indicator from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) or from the action of the Prophet's companions (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). (Stagnant Water / Al-Ma' Al-Da'im): is the remaining, staying, still water that does not flow, moving only by the action of an actor, be it human or animal and the like. The rationale for this; the prohibition of bathing in stagnant water whether for Ghusl of Janabah or otherwise, they said is that stagnant water is predominantly prone to impurity remaining in it, while flowing water purifies itself by its flow and by the abundance of water in it. That is why the poet said: I have seen that the standing of water spoils it.........If it flows it becomes good, and if it does not flow, it does not become good. This is known; if water is still, whenever impurity comes to it and occurs in it, it generally becomes impure if it is small. As for that which flows, it meets other [water] and likewise impurity is removed from it by its flow in the earth. Scholars differed regarding if a Junub (person in state of major impurity) bathes in stagnant water, what is the ruling of that water? Depending on their disagreement regarding the amount by which water is considered small so it does not repel impurity. This disagreement is regarding small water; as for large water, they agree it does not become 'used' (Musta'mal), like a river, sea, large pond, and the like which exceed the limit of smallness by their consensus. But they differed on the limit of 'small', and upon it is built their disagreement regarding the impurity of used water. Scholars differed on three opinions; and they are narrations from Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, although one of the narrations is considered strange (Gharib). First Opinion: They said it remains pure (Tahir) but is not purifying (Mutahhir). They said it can be drunk and cooked with, but ritual impurity (Hadath) cannot be removed by it, such as Wudu and Ghusl of Janabah. This is the well-known view from Ahmad and the view of the Shafi'is.

text: Second Opinion: They said it is impure (Najis). If a Junub bathes in stagnant water, that indicates its impurity. So it cannot be drunk, cooked with, bathed with, nor performed ablution with, a fortiori. This is the view of Abu Hanifa and, as mentioned, a narration from Imam Ahmad. Some followers [of the Hanbali school] like Abu Ya'la Al-Hanbali, Ibn Aqil, and others interpreted it, but it is a narration far from him [Ahmad], may Allah have mercy on him. Perhaps some followers understood Ahmad's saying incorrectly and recounted that water becomes impure if a Junub bathes in it; otherwise, the Fiqh of Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, is far from that. Third Opinion: They said that water in which a Junub bathes remains on its purifying nature (Tahuriyyah), and that it is Pure and Purifying (Tahir Mutahhir). This is the view of the majority of scholars. It is narrated from Sufyan Al-Thawri, as well as Malik bin Anas, Al-Shafi'i, and Ahmad. It is the view of the verifying scholars like Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him. They said: Water in which a Junub bathes remains on its original state, and it does not transfer from its original state except with evidence from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) against the Junub bathing in stagnant water is not related to the purity or impurity of the water after bathing in it. Rather, it is for a cause: either discipline from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), or preventing bathing in stagnant [water] so that a person does not become careless about bathing in it in any condition, thus spoiling the water by changing its attributes, or other reasons whose wisdom is hidden. It is not said that the water is impure or transferred from its original state except with evidence or an obvious cause explicitly stated by the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His saying: And for Al-Bukhari: «None of you should urinate in stagnant water that does not flow, then bathe in it.» This narration which Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated saying: Abu Al-Yaman told us, saying Shu'ayb informed us from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. And in it is his saying: «then bathe in it»:

text: This narration brought a ruling that some scholars derived from it, saying: The prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is linked to the combination [of actions], meaning a man should not urinate in stagnant water and then bathe in it. But if he bathes in it without urinating, there is no harm. Those who held this view held fast to this narration. His saying: And for Muslim: «from it» (Minhu): The narration of Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, with his saying: «from it» was narrated by him, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Muhammad bin Rafi' told us, Abdul-Razzaq told us from Ma'mar bin Rashid from Hammam bin Munabbih from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. In it is evidence for the opinion of some scholars that the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is not specific to the Junub immersing himself in the water, but his prohibition (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also includes bathing from that water even if he scoops from it. This narration appears, and Allah knows best, to have been narrated by meaning (Bi-al-Ma'na); otherwise, the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is apparent from the explanation of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, when Abu Al-Sa'ib asked him, may Allah have mercy on him: How should he do, O Abu Huraira? He said: He should take it by scooping (Yatnawaluhu Tanawulan). This contradicts Abu Huraira's, may Allah be pleased with him, explanation of this [specific wording of the] narration. His saying: And for Abu Dawud: «And nor bathe in it from Janabah»:

text: This narration was narrated by Abu Dawud, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Musaddad told us, Yahya bin Saeed Al-Ansari told us, from Muhammad bin Ajlan, from his father, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. Imam Ahmad also narrated it from Yahya, from Ibn Ajlan with the same chain. By the apparent look of the chain, Muhammad bin Ajlan and his father are trustworthy (Thiqat), and their hadiths are upright. However, Ibn Ajlan's contradiction in this narration necessitates consideration and pause regarding it. No one narrated the combination of [the prohibition of] bathing in stagnant water and the prohibition of a Junub person bathing in stagnant water except Muhammad bin Ajlan. His solitary narration necessitates doubt regarding the establishment of this wording. Rather, what is apparent is its anomaly (Shudhudh), as the report is singular and he contradicted trustworthy narrators in it, alongside the fact that Ibn Ajlan has some lightness in his precision (Dabt) and is not among the trustworthy Hafiz (memorisers). The hadith is well-known from Abu Hurairah, narrated by a group of his companions such as Al-A'raj, Ibn Sirin, Hammam, Hamid bin Abdur-Rahman, and others, and Ibn Ajlan was solitary in narrating from his father with this wording. What must be known is the necessity of care and alertness to such differences in hadiths of rulings (Ahkam). Jurists often overlook this, so you see opinions varying based on the variation of the multiple wordings of the hadith, as in this report. If the wordings were collected, that would become clear. This occurs very frequently in books of Fiqh; hadiths are often narrated from one path and one source, yet their wordings vary because they were narrated by meaning or narrated without precision. Despite this, the opinions of jurists multiply with the multiplicity of these narrations. This is what one should be alert to in many issues of Fiqh and its evidences. If these multiple wordings for a single hadith were edited and the authentic one among them known, the opinions relying on [the weak wordings] would be weakened.

text: What must also be known is that hadiths in many chapters agree on a specific ruling that the hadith came to establish, which is the reason for the hadith's occurrence and the narrators' transmission of it. The narrators focus on transmitting the report and preserving the wording that carries the ruling of the hadith, but they do not take care to preserve what came incidentally in the hadith, such as mentioning a story or another wording that does not stipulate the ruling. Thus, the wordings vary and differ. This occurs very frequently, so these [jurists] hold onto those wordings to interpret the ruling, while the ruling is singular if stripped of those wordings that came incidentally in the context of the hadith, which narrators often do not prioritize. Despite the source of the hadith being one, and it being certain that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said it in one instance, opinions divide in interpreting the ruling based on the difference of those incidental wordings that are not fundamental to the report. For example, you find difference in the report of Al-Miqdad: 'Perform ablution (Wudu) and sprinkle water on your private part' or 'Wash your penis and perform ablution.' The text came, and for its sake the report was transmitted, regarding the lack of [necessity for] Ghusl (full bath) from Madhi (pre-seminal fluid) and that washing the penis and Wudu suffice. However, some held onto [specific wordings] and opinions divided according to the context of the report: Is Wudu valid before cleaning the private parts or not? Is Wudu valid before washing the penis or not? This issue occurs frequently, so one must be alert to it. *************************************** 7- From a man who accompanied the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade 'that a woman bathes with the leftover water of a man, or a man with the leftover water of a woman, but let them scoop [water] together.' Narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Nasa'i, and its chain is authentic (Sahih). This hadith was narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawud, and Al-Nasa'i from the hadith of Abu Awanah, from Dawud bin Abdullah Al-Awdi, from Hamid bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Himyari, who said: I heard a man who accompanied the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) just as Abu Hurairah accompanied him for four years.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This hadith has an authentic chain. Some scholars have criticized it with reasons that do not impair it. Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, criticized it, and Al-Bayhaqi, may Allah have mercy on him, indicated that it has the ruling of Mursal (disconnected). However, the anonymity (Jahalah) of the Companion here does not harm, and this is the view of the generality of scholars. No one disagreed with this except Ibn Hazm and Abu Ishaq Al-Isfarayini, as they said that the anonymity of the Companion causes harm, justifying this with an unacceptable reasoning. The scholars hold that the anonymity of the Companion does not harm because Allah, Glorified and Exalted be He, has declared their integrity in His Great Book and was pleased with them, Glorified and Exalted be He. This is stated in the Book of Allah, the Majestic and Exalted, and is a matter of consensus among the righteous predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them. Among those who stated this are Imam Ahmad and Al-Humaydi, while Al-Bayhaqi was inconsistent on this, may Allah have mercy on them all. Imam Ahmad said: If a man from the Tabi'in says 'A man from the Companions told me' and does not name him, the hadith is authentic. Al-Humaydi said: If the chain is authentic from trustworthy narrators to a man from the Companions, it is a proof even if he does not name him. Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, his statement does not stand against the statements of the Imams of this field; he is not one to be contrasted with Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, Ibn Al-Madini, Al-Daraqutni, Ibn Ma'in, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, and their likes. He is one of those who apply the apparent meaning in criticism and overlooks indications (Qara'in), like many of the later scholars such as Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi and the like. Indeed, Ibn Hazm has delusions in identifying narrators and their names that are not usually found among the great Imams. He was deluded regarding the name of Hammad, making him Ibn Zaid while the correct one is Ibn Salamah, for the narrator from him is Musa bin Ismail. Also his lack of knowledge regarding Dawud, the narrator of this hadith, as will come, and other instances which I have not seen among the critical Hafiz scholars, and if found among them, it is very rare.

text: Dawud bin Abdullah Al-Awdi was declared trustworthy by Imam Ahmad as well as by Ibn Ma'in, may Allah have mercy on them. Ibn Ma'in, may Allah have mercy on him, was quoted regarding Dawud bin Yazid Al-Awdi as saying: 'He is nothing' (i.e., weak). Hafiz Al-Mizzi, may Allah have mercy on him, imagined that this ruling was regarding Dawud bin Abdullah Al-Awdi, the narrator of this report, so he mentioned this criticism and wounding in the entry of Dawud bin Abdullah Al-Awdi in his book *Al-Tahdhib*. This is a delusion that should be noted, for Ibn Ma'in's statement regarding Dawud Al-Awdi: 'He is nothing,' did not refer to Dawud bin Abdullah, but rather Dawud bin Yazid. Dawud bin Yazid Al-Awdi is known to be weak. Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, criticized this report based on Dawud Al-Awdi due to his ignorance of his status. He said, may Allah have mercy on him: 'If this Dawud is the uncle of Ibn Idris, then he is weak, otherwise he is unknown (Majhul).' A group of scholars, such as Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi, critiqued him, mentioning that Al-Humaydi declared this report authentic. He wrote a treatise to Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, explaining the authenticity of this report and clarifying the status of Dawud bin Abdullah Al-Awdi, stating that he is a known trustworthy narrator, neither unknown nor weak. He said, may Allah have mercy on him: 'I do not know if Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, retracted his statement or not.' The witness in this is that the chain of this report is authentic. It was authenticated by some scholars such as Al-Humaydi, Ibn Al-Qattan Al-Fasi, the author Ibn Hajar here, and others. Al-Maymuni reported from Imam Ahmad his criticism of the reports narrated regarding the prohibition of purifying oneself with the leftover water of a woman and regarding its permissibility, considering them inconsistent (Mudtarib).

text: This indicates that Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, did not stipulate authenticity in his *Musnad*, but rather stipulated fame (Shuhrah). The meaning of fame is what is known among the Hafiz scholars and became famous, even if it is not famous or known among those below them; it does not mean fame among the terminologists. Imam Ahmad said to his son Abdullah when he asked him about a weak hadith he included in the *Musnad*: 'I only intended the famous in the *Musnad*, and I left people under the cover of Allah. If I wanted to include only what is authentic according to me, I would not have narrated this *Musnad* except a little bit.' This was recounted by more than one Imam and a group of Hanbalis like Abu Ya'la, Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn Al-Qayyim, and others. Therefore, you find that Imam Ahmad narrated hadiths in his *Musnad* yet criticized them, indeed some he denounced. Examples of this are very many, including this hadith, and also what Imam Ahmad narrated in his *Musnad* via Abu Al-Umays Utbah from Al-Ala' bin Abdur-Rahman bin Yaqub from his father from Abu Hurairah, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'When it is the middle of Sha'ban, hold off from fasting until it is Ramadan.' Harb reported from Ahmad his saying regarding this hadith: 'This is a rejected (Munkar) hadith; Al-Ala' did not narrate a hadith more rejected than this, and Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi would not narrate it.' Among them is also what he narrated in his *Musnad* from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, Abu Saeed, and others: 'There is no ablution for one who does not mention the name of Allah upon it.' He said: 'Nothing is established regarding this from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' Among them is what he narrated in his *Musnad* from the hadith of Ismail from Qais from Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali who said: 'We used to consider gathering at the family of the deceased and making food after his burial as wailing.' Abu Dawud reported from Imam Ahmad his saying regarding it: 'It has no basis.' And among them is what he narrated in his *Musnad* from the hadith of Baqiyyah from Uthman bin Zafar from Hashim from Ibn Umar who said: 'Whoever buys a garment for ten dirhams containing one dirham of haram (unlawful money), Allah will not accept a prayer from him as long as he wears it.' He said: Then he put his fingers in his ears and said: 'Deafness [be upon them] if I did not hear the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say it.' Ahmad said: 'It has no chain (Isnad).' By this phrase, he means it has no chain that can be relied upon.

text: It is akin to hadiths that are narrated but have no chain at all. Likewise, among the examples is this hadith which is with us, as we mentioned regarding the prohibition of bathing with the leftover water of a man and a woman. This report regarding his prohibition (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that a woman bathes with the leftover water of a man and a man with the leftover water of a woman, scholars have differed regarding the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) therein: - The literalists (Ahl al-Zahir) went to the view, and it is narrated from Imam Ahmad and is the view of the Hanbalis, may Allah have mercy on them, that the prohibition here is for unlawfulness (Tahrim); because the default regarding the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is that it is interpreted as unlawfulness.

text: - A group of scholars, and it is a view of the Malikis, went to the view that the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is for propriety (Tanzih) and is interpreted as dislike (Karahah). This is due to the arrival of several reports from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as well as from the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), that a man may bathe with the leftover water of a woman. Al-Bukhari and others narrated from Malik from Nafi' from Abdullah bin Umar who said: 'Men and women used to perform ablution together during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' Also, what the authors of the Sunan (Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah) narrated, and also Imam Ahmad, Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Hibban, and others narrated from the hadith of Simak bin Harb from Ikrimah from Abdullah bin Abbas: Some of the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) bathed in a large bowl. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to bathe from it, so his wife said: 'I was Junub (in a state of major impurity).' The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Water does not become Junub.' This report was criticized by some scholars and authenticated by others. It was authenticated by Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, and Ibn Hajar as in his book here. Some scholars criticized it, and Imam Ahmad hesitated regarding it due to the status of Simak bin Harb. Simak bin Harb was declared trustworthy by Ibn Ma'in, and Al-Nasa'i said of him: 'There is no harm in him.' Ibn Al-Madini and Yaqub bin Shaybah said: 'He is inconsistent (Mudtarib) in narrating from Ikrimah.' Al-Daraqutni said: 'If Sufyan, Shu'bah, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrate from him, then his hadiths are sound.' In this report, Sufyan narrated from him as in Imam Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrated from him as in Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, Al-Tabarani, and others. Also, Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj narrated it from him. The wordings differed; Shu'bah, Sufyan, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrated it with the wording: 'Water is not made impure by anything,' which is the correct one, and it is not authentic with the wording 'Water does not become Junub.' Mostly, if Shu'bah, Sufyan, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrate from him, it is...

text: ...indicative of his precision in this report, and that this report is upright. The reliance is to look, along with that, at the uprightness of the hadith, lack of strangeness or inconsistency, and that he is not solitary in reporting what trustworthy Hafiz scholars have not brought. Al-Bukhari narrated from Ikrimah, the freed slave of Abdullah bin Abbas, in his Sahih. Here is an issue that should be noted: When narrations like this exist where a narrator whom Al-Bukhari included narrates from a narrator whom Imam Muslim included, it is not said regarding such a report that it is 'according to the condition of Al-Bukhari' nor 'according to the condition of Muslim.' Nor is it said 'according to the condition of the Sahih' without referencing Bukhari or Muslim. Rather, it is said 'its narrators are the narrators of the Sahih' or 'its narrators were included in the Sahih.' We have mentioned that such phrases do not indicate the authentication of the hadith, for Simak bin Harb's narration from Ikrimah contains inconsistency as mentioned by Ibn Al-Madini as well as Yaqub bin Shaybah, even though Imam Muslim included Simak bin Harb in his narrations from other than Ikrimah, and Al-Bukhari included Ikrimah, the freed slave of Abdullah bin Abbas, without Simak bin Harb's narration from him. So it cannot be said that it is according to the condition of one of them, let alone the condition of both. The saying of some: 'Its narrators are the narrators of the Sahih' does not avail in authenticating this report or other reports. Claiming 'according to the condition of the Sahih' for hadiths is something many have been lenient about, looking at the apparent chains and judging so. This is incorrect, for there are things other than the sequence of narrators that must be looked into, which are strangeness, singularity, lack of contradiction, and the soundness of the text (Matn). Hadiths have been found which were claimed to be according to the condition of Bukhari or Muslim or both, yet their texts contain objectionability (Nakarah) and strangeness. This is incorrect, as the Two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) look at the texts just as they look at the chains and the men. This has been overlooked by many who attribute themselves to knowledge in the current era. Based on this, the hadith of Simak bin Harb from Ikrimah is of three types:

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: First: What he narrated from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas and was solitary in it, without being corroborated; objectionability (Nakarah) dominates it, so it is rejected. An example is what Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah narrated from the hadith of Simak from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas who said: A Bedouin came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: 'I saw the crescent moon.' He said: 'Do you testify that there is no god but Allah? Do you testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'O Bilal, announce to the people to fast tomorrow.' The correct view regarding it is that it is Mursal (disconnected). A group such as Sufyan Al-Thawri and others narrated it from Simak from Ikrimah as Mursal, and Hafiz scholars like Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Nasa'i considered that correct. Hafiz scholars like Ibn Al-Madini, Ahmad Al-Ajli, Al-Daraqutni, and others rejected Simak's solitary narrations from Ikrimah. Second: What he narrated from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas, and his early companions like Shu'bah, Sufyan, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrated it from him. This type is examined for the uprightness of its text and lack of strangeness and objectionability; if it is so, it is accepted. Third: What he narrated from Ikrimah from other than Ibn Abbas, like Aisha and others, and was not among those whose text is denounced and did not stand alone with a fundamental principle; it is carried as upright and authentic as long as it is not contradicted. As Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tayalisi, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Simak from Ikrimah from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon me one day and said: 'Do you have anything?' I said: 'No.' He said: 'Then I am fasting.' This is authentic, authenticated by Hafiz scholars like Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi, and others. Regarding the issue of bathing with leftover water, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) bathed with the leftover water of Maimunah, may Allah be pleased with her, as in Sahih Muslim from the hadith of Abdullah bin Abbas. Thus, a man washing with a woman's leftover water is permissible and sufficient, and that is not interpreted as unlawful, combining the reports that came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as well as from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah be pleased with them. *************************************** 8- And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to bathe with the leftover water of Maimunah (may Allah be pleased with her). Narrated by Muslim.
