text: This hadith was narrated by Imam Muslim from the hadith of Muhammad bin Bakr from Ibn Jurayj from Amr bin Dinar who said: 'The most I know, and what crosses my mind, is that Abu Al-Sha'tha told me from Abdullah bin Abbas that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) bathed with the leftover water of Maimunah, may Allah be pleased with her.' This report diverts what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prohibiting a man from bathing with a woman's leftover water or a woman with a man's leftover water from unlawfulness; it diverted it from unlawfulness to dislike of propriety (Karahat Al-Tanzih), otherwise the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would not have done something he had forbidden. It also contains evidence that water remains upon its purity and purifying nature, staying on its original state not diverting to anything else. Since the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did that and his Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, did it, this indicates the continuity of water in its original state. And that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he forbade a man bathing with a woman's leftover water or a woman with a man's leftover water, it was a prohibition of dislike, and that it is preferable for a man to bathe after a woman without her leftover water, and a woman to bathe after a man without his leftover water, or they scoop from one vessel together. That is what the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) drew attention to by forbidding it, a prohibition of dislike and not a prohibition of unlawfulness.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: In the chain of this report, there are issues mentioned by the scholars of Hadith, may Allah have mercy on them, regarding the saying of Amr bin Dinar: 'The most I know, and what crosses my mind, is that Abu Al-Sha'tha told me...'. He fell into doubt, may Allah have mercy on him. Despite that, Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, included this report in his Sahih, even though Amr bin Dinar had some doubt regarding Abu Al-Sha'tha narrating to him from Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them. The answer to this is that the doubt of trustworthy Hafiz scholars like Amr bin Dinar is like the certainty of others, especially if their conjecture leans towards something. Therefore, Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj said: 'Mis'ar's doubt is dearer to me than the certainty of others.' He also said this regarding Ibn Awn. It was narrated that Shu'bah asked Ayyub about a hadith and he said, 'I doubt it,' so he said to him, 'Your doubt is dearer to me than the certainty of others.' For if a trustworthy narrator doubts a matter and leans towards one side, as in Amr bin Dinar's narration here, it indicates his extreme caution and precision, unlike one with light precision or a truthful narrator (Saduq) or trustworthy narrators who are not known for memorization or precision, for if they doubt, one pauses regarding it. Indeed, the scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, have said: If a Hafiz narrates a hadith from his Sheikh and his Sheikh denies having told him that report, his hadith is authentic. If the Sheikh denies having told him that report, it is either because forgetfulness occurred to the Sheikh or some heedlessness and the like. Narrations have come from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with chains containing such instances; some Sheikhs denied having told students, even though the students were Hafiz scholars, and the Hafiz scholars accepted their narrations. Al-Bukhari and Muslim included such instances in their Sahihs, just as Imam Muslim included such doubt here in the hadith of Amr bin Dinar from Abu Al-Sha'tha from Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them. ***************************************

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: 9- And for the authors of the Sunan: Some of the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) bathed in a large bowl. He came to bathe from it, so she said to him: 'I was Junub.' He said: 'Water does not become Junub.' Authenticated by Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Khuzaymah. This hadith is the hadith of Abdullah bin Abbas. We alluded to it previously in the hadith before last, that it is the hadith of Abdullah bin Abbas, narrated from him by Ikrimah, narrated from Ikrimah by Simak bin Harb, narrated from Simak bin Harb by Sufyan Al-Thawri, and with Sufyan, Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj and Abu Al-Ahwas narrated it. These are trustworthy Hafiz scholars; if they narrate a hadith from Simak bin Harb, even if from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas, it is mostly upright. It might have something objectionable and be rejected; but these [narrators] select hadiths from their Sheikhs. Al-Daraqutni, may Allah have mercy on him, said about Simak bin Harb: 'If Sufyan, Shu'bah, and Abu Al-Ahwas narrate from him, his hadiths are sound.' Simak bin Harb's narration from Ikrimah contains some inconsistency (Idtirab), as recounted by Ibn Al-Madini and Yaqub bin Shaybah, and also Ahmad bin Abdullah Al-Ajli, may Allah have mercy on him. Otherwise, Simak bin Harb himself is among the trustworthy narrators; Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy, and Al-Nasa'i said of him: 'There is no harm in him, but there is something in his hadith.' Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, hesitated regarding him due to his extreme caution regarding Simak bin Harb's status, for no one other than Simak bin Harb narrates it; it was not narrated except through Simak bin Harb. The hadith with this wording mentioned by the author is not authentic. The correct [wording] is what the trustworthy companions of Simak, like Shu'bah, Sufyan, and Abu Al-Ahwas, agreed upon: 'Water does not become impure' or 'Nothing makes it impure.' We have previously discussed it and Simak bin Harb's narration from Ikrimah, the freed slave of Ibn Abbas, in detail.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: In this report, there is also evidence, as we mentioned previously, that it diverts the prohibition of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding a man bathing with the leftover water of a woman, or a woman with the leftover water of a man—and that they should scoop together—and that the prohibition implies dislike, specifically dislike of propriety, not a dislike of unlawfulness. Otherwise, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would not have said to his wife, may Allah be pleased with her: 'Water does not become impure,' and bathed from it (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). 10- And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'The purification of the vessel of one of you, if a dog licks in it, is to wash it seven times, the first of them with soil.' Narrated by Muslim. This hadith was narrated by Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Zuhayr bin Harb told us, Ismail bin Ibrahim told us, from Hisham bin Hassan, from Muhammad bin Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'If the dog licks': 'Wulugh' (licking/lapping) here is: Drinking with the tongue. This is specific to the dog and similar predatory animals. Licking does not occur except with a liquid like water and the like. From this, it is taken—as scholars have taken—that if a dog places its tongue on something solid and the like, this does not have the ruling of liquid, and it is not washed seven times. Rather, the part where the dog placed its tongue is taken and washed like other impurities or removed and thrown away. It is not said that that spot is washed seven times, because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) restricted that to licking ('Wulugh'), and licking only happens in drinking. This wording which came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) here in his saying: 'If it licks', we mentioned that it is specific to the dog and what is in its ruling among predators. However, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) specified this ruling to the dog and did not generalize it to all other predators by his saying: 'If the dog licks in the vessel of one of you.' This is specific to the dog and does not encompass all other predators.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: It has come from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), his saying: 'If it drinks.' It is known that a dog does not 'drink' (shariba) but rather 'licks' (yaligh), and this is known among the Arabs. This came in the Two Sahihs: from the hadith of Malik from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'If the dog drinks.' Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr, may Allah have mercy on him, said that Imam Malik was solitary in this wording, i.e., 'If it drinks.' The truth is that Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, was not solitary in this wording 'If it drinks.' What appears, and Allah knows best, is that it is from someone above him or someone below him, or that this report was narrated by meaning from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This wording came from other than Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him. Indeed, more than one narrator reported this news from Imam Malik without mentioning the wording 'If it drinks,' but rather said: 'If it licks.' This came in Abu Ubaid's book (*Al-Tahur*) from the hadith of Ismail bin Umar from Malik from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he said: 'If it licks.' Also, Ibn Majah narrated it from the hadith of Ruh bin Ubadah from Malik from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: 'If it licks,' and did not mention 'if it drinks.' This indicates that Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, brought the hadith in its proper form, and that this [variation] is either from Abu Al-Zinad or from those who narrated from Imam Malik. Also supporting the view that this report came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) by meaning and came with the wording 'If it drinks'...

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: ...and that what is authentic from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is 'If it licks,' is that it came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) via paths other than Imam Malik. Ibn Al-Mundhir narrated from the hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad from his father from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he said: 'If it drinks.' Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad followed Imam Malik here. Shu'ayb bin Abi Hamzah also narrated it from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saying: 'If it drinks.' This indicates that Imam Malik was not solitary in his path with this wording. It was also narrated from other than the path of Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurairah; it came in Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Al-Mundhir via two paths from Hisham bin Hassan from Ibn Sirin from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he said: 'If the dog drinks in the vessel of one of you,' coming with the word 'drinks'. What appears, and Allah knows best, is that his saying at the beginning of this report 'If it drinks' came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) by meaning, and that it came metaphorically so the listener would understand, and so it would come to mind that the intent is drinking and not just the dog's tongue touching the spot. However, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intended by that report, as we mentioned, licking ('Wulugh'). Licking does not happen except with liquid, and if a dog's tongue touches something solid and the like, it is not washed seven times nor with soil. Rather, that spot is removed if it is solid, like solid ghee and the like; what the dog touched with his tongue is removed, and it is not said that it is washed seven times etc., then that thing which the dog's tongue touched is used. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'If the dog licks': The dog here is a known beast among predators. This ruling is specific to dogs and does not include other predators according to the generality of scholars.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: However, they differed regarding the pig: Is it washed seven times and its ruling is like the ruling of the dog as came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)? - The majority of scholars hold that the pig does not have the same ruling as the dog, and that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) specified that for the dog and did not generalize it. Otherwise, if it were general, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would have said: 'If it is licked in the vessel of one of you,' without mentioning the dog specifically. - Some scholars went to the view that the pig is washed seven times, one of them with soil, justifying their reasoning by saying that the pig is more impure than the dog, so that analogy (Qiyas) would be *a fortiori* (more deserving). However, this is not conceded; because the Prophet's specific mention of the dog has a wisdom, and his specification of its saliva has a known wisdom. It is known that there are things which are filthy, yet the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not stipulate that number, nor did he stipulate soil except for the dog, which indicates that the dog has a distinct characteristic known in the knowledge of Allah, Exalted be He, regarding impurity, the removal of which the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) specified by washing seven times, the first with soil, as came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The 'dog' here includes all types of dogs, even those the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) permitted keeping, such as hunting dogs, livestock dogs, guard dogs, and the like. Some scholars said that what the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) permitted, like guard dogs and hunting dogs, are excluded from this. They said that this is more fitting with the tolerance of Islam; since the Wise Lawgiver permitted keeping the dog—while the default is that whoever keeps one has earned a sin and it is among the things that reduce deeds—then the impurity is overlooked. Just as Allah forgave the sin, the impurity is forgiven because it is a matter of widespread hardship (Umum al-Balwa), for guard dogs and hunting dogs mix with people causing hardship, so forgiving their impurity is from the Wise Lawgiver indicating the tolerance of Islam. However, this view is not conceded, for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stated this generally and did not restrict it (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to hunting dogs nor livestock dogs nor others which the Prophet excluded. If the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wanted to specify something, he would have specified it just as he specified hunting dogs and others from the exception to the prohibition he made. This is the correct view supported by evidences: that the impurity of the dog is general, and the command to wash is general for all types of dogs. Is the impurity of the dog in its mouth and saliva or in its whole body? The majority of scholars from the Shafi'is, Hanafis, and Hanbalis hold that the impurity of the dog is complete in all its body, except that washing seven times applies only to what the dog licked, while the rest of the dog's body is considered impure. They justified this by saying: If the dog's saliva is impure, and saliva comes from the inside of the dog, from its intestines and the like, which is what the animal's body grows from, this indicates that it grows from impurity.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Imam Malik and Dawud Al-Zahiri, and it is a view of the Zahiris in general, held that the dog's impurity is in its mouth and saliva. They reasoned saying: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered washing the dog's impurity only if it licks, even though dogs mixing with people, like guard dogs and what the Prophet permitted, is more frequent than their licking in vessels, yet the Prophet did not order anything regarding precaution to remove the impurity of the dog from its body and the like. This view is rejected, for the Prophet's omission of mentioning the impurity of the dog's body, which is a matter of widespread hardship, does not mean the dog's body is not impure. Rather, the utmost it indicates is that the dog's body and hair do not fall under the ruling of the dog's licking, so it is not washed seven times nor with soil. This is the utmost understood from the Prophet's text, meaning that the ruling on the impurity of the dog's saliva and spittle is more severe than the impurity of its body; this is the utmost the text from the Prophet indicates. Washing seven times is obligatory according to the generality of scholars, and washing the dog's saliva or the vessel in which the dog licks is not sufficient with less than that. Whoever washes less than that, it does not suffice for him according to the generality of jurists, may Allah have mercy on them. However, they differed regarding washing with soil: Is it obligatory or not? The Hanafis and Malikis held that the obligation is washing seven times, and that washing with soil is not obligatory. They reasoned by saying: The washing with soil has different narrations regarding it and its placement from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), which indicates the Lawgiver's lack of emphasis on it, otherwise the narrators would have preserved it accurately.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The majority of scholars, and it is a view of Al-Shafi'i and Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on them, held that washing with soil is obligatory, and that whoever washes the vessel from a dog's licking seven times but does not wash it with soil, it does not suffice for him. They used as evidence the apparent meaning of what came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in this report, the hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, and that it is established from the Prophet and there is no dust on it. They argued that the variation among narrators in mentioning the place of the soil washing or doubting it does not mean it is not established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Just as some narrators doubted it and were inconsistent regarding it, there are narrators who preserved it accurately from the Prophet and established its place. This is known to those who contemplate the reports of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and contemplate the paths of Abu Hurairah's hadith and other reports that came regarding washing the vessel from the dog's licking. This is the correct view supported by the apparent evidences from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)—that the seven washings and the washing with soil are obligatory, and that whoever washes the vessel less than that or does not wash it with soil, it does not suffice. This has been known by experience and is also known among medical experts that soil has a merit over other cleaning agents, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not specify it except due to knowledge of the Unseen that Allah informed him of. {Nor does he speak from [his own] inclination. It is not but a revelation revealed.} His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'If the dog licks in the vessel of one of you': The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) mentioned the vessel here and restricted the licking to it. We mentioned that the majority of scholars hold that washing applies only to the dog licking in liquid, and that if the dog's tongue touches something solid, it is not washed [seven times]. However, scholars differed regarding the rest of the dog's body if it is dipped into the vessel and the like.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The majority of scholars hold that if the dog's body, like its paw, leg, or hair, is dipped into a vessel of water or other drink like milk, juice, etc., it is not washed seven times. Rather, if the water is plentiful and none of its characteristics change, it remains pure. If any of its characteristics change, then it becomes impure. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, held that the dog—its ear, mouth, saliva, and leg—if dipped into liquid, is washed seven times, one of them with soil, generalizing that ruling. However, this is not supported by evidence. What came from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is 'licking in the vessel', and this only occurs in liquid and only from the tongue of the dog and other predators. This is specific to the dog due to the Prophet's specification by saying 'If the dog licks'. There are consecutive restrictions from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in this report: First: by saying 'If it licks', he specified licking, which is general. Then he said 'the dog', specifying it from other predators, which indicates the ruling is specific to the dog and does not extend to other predators. Then he said (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) 'in the vessel of one of you', which indicates its restriction to drink/liquid, and that this does not apply to the rest of the dog's body like its ear, or dipping its mouth without licking, or dipping its foot; for that does not necessitate washing seven times nor the washing with soil, due to the apparent text from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in this report: 'The first of them with soil': This is what is correct from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). As for what came as 'the first or the last', it is due to doubt, not choice; a doubt by some narrators. The correct version is 'the first of them'. The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: And in a wording by him: 'Let him spill it out':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This wording was narrated by Imam Muslim, may Allah have mercy on him, from the hadith of Ali bin Hajar from Ali bin Mushir from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih and Abu Razin from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. This wording is anomalous (*Shadh*). Ali bin Mushir contradicted all the companions of Al-A'mash who narrated this report from him. Ali bin Mushir is trustworthy (*Thiqah*) and is known and famous for narration, and the Group [of hadith scholars] narrated from him. Although he is a known trustworthy narrator, he contradicted the trustworthy Hafiz scholars from the companions of Al-A'mash, may Allah have mercy on him, for they did not mention this addition. A group narrated it from Al-A'mash, including Shu'bah bin Al-Hajjaj, as well as Abu Mu'awiyah as in Imam Ahmad, Ismail bin Zakaria in Imam Muslim, and Hammad bin Usama in Ibn Abi Shaybah. Others also narrated it. Shu'bah and Abu Mu'awiyah are among the most trustworthy and firm people regarding the hadith of Al-A'mash. Also, a group narrated it from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah without mentioning the wording 'Let him spill it out.' This addition is an anomalous addition; the Hafiz scholars have stated its anomaly. Imam Al-Nasa'i stated its anomaly in his Sunan and said: 'I do not know anyone of the narrators who agreed with Ali bin Mushir on this wording, meaning: Let him spill it out.' Ibn Abd al-Barr also stated this, saying: 'This wording was not brought by the trustworthy Hafiz companions of Al-A'mash like Shu'bah and others.' Hamza Al-Kinani, who is one of the critical Hafiz scholars, also stated its anomaly, saying it is not preserved (*Mahfuzah*). Thus, it is an anomalous addition that is not established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in terms of narration.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Those who say that the dog's licking in the vessel indicates the impurity of the water, whether much or little, used this [addition] as evidence. This view is incorrect in terms of deriving it from this narration, although it has a valid aspect in terms of the conclusion. For the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he said: 'If the dog licks in the vessel of one of you, let him wash it seven times,' his saying 'let him wash it seven times' indicates the impurity of the vessel. From what did the vessel become impure? It became impure from that water which is in it. It is known that the dog licked the water and perhaps did not touch the vessel with its tongue, so the water transferred the impurity to the vessel, making it impure, and the Lawgiver obligated washing it seven times. However, this addition implies two meanings from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): First meaning: The impurity of this water absolutely, whether little or much. This is not conceded unless the water is so little that it does not repel impurity. But if it is plentiful, like in large vessels and the like where it is difficult for the dog's saliva to spread, then it does not become impure because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) generalized the purity of water unless its taste, color, or smell changes, as passed previously. However, if it is little, like small vessels, it becomes impure even if none of its [qualities] change, by the text of the Prophet and his command to wash the vessel seven times. This addition implies a second matter: The Prophet's command to spill the water and not use it for anything. This is not conceded because this addition is not authentic from the Prophet. Rather, it is legislated to use the water and not waste it by adding it to other water so it increases and the impurity is removed by the abundance of water. If we said this addition was authentic, it would be obligatory not to use this water and obligatory to spill the water in which the dog licked. But this addition is not authentic, so acting upon this command is not correct. The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: And for Al-Tirmidhi: 'The first or the last with soil':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This narration was narrated by Imam Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Sawwar told us, from Al-Mu'tamir bin Sulayman, from Ayyub, from Ibn Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. This narration is with doubt, not choice. His saying 'the first or the last' is a doubt [from the narrator], not a choice. Evidence for this is that the companions of Ibn Sirin narrated this report from him without doubt; among them are Hisham bin Hassan, Qatadah bin Di'amah, Habib bin Al-Shahid, Al-Awza'i, and other Hafiz scholars narrated this report from Ibn Sirin from Abu Hurairah without doubting in it. The correct version in this narration from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is 'the first of them' as came in Imam Muslim. 11- From Abu Qatadah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding the cat: 'It is not impure (Najas); it is only one of those who go around among you (Tawwafeen).' Narrated by the Four, and authenticated by Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Khuzaymah. This hadith was narrated by Imam Ahmad, Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Ibn Khuzaymah, Ibn Hibban, Al-Bayhaqi, and others. All of them narrated it from the hadith of Imam Malik bin Anas from Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha from his wife Humaydah bint Ubayd bin Rifa'ah from Kabshah from Abu Qatadah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This hadith has been criticized by some scholars for ignorance (*Jahalah*) in its chain. Hafiz Ibn Mandah criticized it, saying: 'It is not authentic by any means.' Ibn Abd al-Barr and Al-Bazzar in his *Musnad* also criticized it, saying: 'It is not authentic in terms of transmission.' Others like Ibn Daqiq al-Eid and Ibn al-Turkumani also criticized it.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: However, their criticism based on ignorance in its chain is rejected. This hadith, although it has some ignorance in its chain—their criticism based on Humaydah bint Ubayd and Kabshah—Humaydah bint Ubayd is with a Damma on the un-dotted Ha' (Humaydah). This is how all companions of Imam Malik narrated it. Yahya bin Yahya Al-Andalusi narrated it from Imam Malik from Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha from his wife 'Hamidah' with a Fatha on the Ha'. Hamidah or Humaydah, according to the most famous view, although she is not famous for narration, Ishaq bin Abi Talha narrated from her, and he is trustworthy. Her son also narrated from her, and Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy. Ibn Hibban mentioned her in his book *Al-Thiqat*. This report was authenticated by a group of scholars. Imam Al-Daraqutni said: 'Its narrators are known trustworthy people.' Al-Nawawi reported authentication of this report from Al-Bayhaqi. Also, Imam Al-Tirmidhi said: 'I asked Muhammad bin Ismail Al-Bukhari about this hadith, and he said: Malik did well in this hadith, and his narration is more correct than the narration of others.'

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This hadith was also authenticated by other later scholars like Imam Al-Nawawi and others. Criticizing it due to Humaydah's ignorance is not conceded, for weakening hadiths purely for ignorance [of a narrator] is not the methodology of the Hafiz scholars. Imam Ahmad, Ibn Al-Madini, Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Daraqutni authenticate some hadiths even if there are unknown narrators in the chain if indications (Qara'in) surround it pointing to the precision of the narration. Humaydah, or Hamidah as Yahya bin Yahya Al-Andalusi said, narrated this hadith from Kabshah. Kabshah is the wife of Abu Qatadah. Ibn Hibban affirmed her companionship and mentioned her among the Companions (*Sahabah*) in his book *Al-Thiqat*, and he also mentioned her among the *Tabi'in*. Perhaps he retracted, which is the best interpretation and better than claiming he was inconsistent. Some said he retracted her status as a Companion and said she was a Tabi'i. In any case, she is in an early layer, and criticizing the report due to her ignorance is not conceded. Therefore, the Hafiz scholars leaned towards strengthening this report, like Imam Al-Daraqutni and Al-Bukhari with his statement: 'Malik did well in this hadith, and his narration is more correct than others,' indicating the uprightness of the text of this hadith. Also, it came in the context of a story from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and this is one of the indications where the hadith of narrators is accepted, whether they are unknown or have light precision, for their narration is accepted if indications surround it.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Furthermore, the Hafiz scholars are lenient regarding the narration of women if they are from an early layer. Thus, Imam Al-Dhahabi says: 'No woman is known to be accused [of lying] or abandoned (*Matrukah*),' meaning in terms of narration. Rather, most women who appear in narrations are among the unknown (*Majahil*) or the covered (*Masturin*), and no woman is known to be among the liars or the abandoned. This is one of the indications where the report is accepted. It is not an absolute rule to accept women's narration, but if indications surround the hadiths of unknown narrators, including women, the Hafiz scholars accept them. This hadith is one of them; it is an upright hadith surrounded by indications. Among them is that its narrators are covered women (*Masturat*) who narrated from an early layer, and it came within a story indicating the precision of the conveyor. It is also supported by the authentication of the Hafiz scholars and their declaring its narrators trustworthy, as Imam Al-Daraqutni said: 'Its narrators are known trustworthy people,' knowing that Humaydah and Kabshah from Abu Qatadah are in its chain. This report was narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban, who only include what is authentic according to them in their Sahihs. His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'It is not Najas': Najas here is from impurity (*Najasah*), opposite to purity (*Taharah*), indicating that the cat and what is in its ruling are among the pure things. The cat (*Hirrah*) is a small animal of the feline family, and what is prevalent (*Umum al-Balwa*) of similar size falls under its ruling. Scholars differed: Is the Prophet's intent here regarding the cat's lack of impurity due to its creation/size, or because it is a widespread hardship (*Umum al-Balwa*) as it is 'of those who go around'? The majority of scholars hold that it is because of the widespread hardship and that it is of 'those who go around' (*Tawwafeen*); therefore, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) explicitly stated that by saying 'It is only one of those who go around among you.'

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The Hanbalis and some scholars went to the view that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intended both matters, and that the Prophet's concession applies to the cat and what is in its ruling regarding its creation which is not impure by the text of the Prophet, or whose impurity is established and is a matter of widespread hardship. According to the majority view, the Prophet's permission and easing regarding the cat is due to the widespread hardship and that it is 'of those who go around', so what is larger than it enters into this ruling due to the shared cause (*Illah*), such as the donkey and the mule, because they are matters of widespread hardship and mix with people. The Cause (*Illah*) mentioned by scholars of Usul in their works is divided into two types: Textual Cause (*Mansusah*) and Deduced Cause (*Mustanbatah*). The Textual Cause is what the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) explicitly states when mentioning a ruling. The Deduced Cause is what the scholar strives to identify and draws analogy upon. If the cause is textual from the Prophet, there is no disagreement in Analogy (*Qiyas*) except among those who deny it from the Zahiris like Ibn Hazm and others. But if the cause is deduced, analogy is not made upon it except with a clear indication supporting this deduction. The cause here regarding the concession for the cat and its purification by the Prophet's judgment that 'it is not impure'—is it a deduced cause or a textual cause? It is a textual cause from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the cause here is his saying 'It is only one of those who go around among you.' This is the cause for which the Prophet made the cat not impure.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: One should not expand in the area of Deduced Cause, because the Wise Lawgiver often mentions rulings, and scholars and jurists deduce from the Prophet's text and draw analogies, thereby falling into contradiction with the Sharia due to the passage of eras and the diversity of people's needs. Whoever contemplates many of the rulings where the people of opinion (*Ahl al-Ra'y*) draw analogies based on Deduced Cause upon other things will see that they expand in it and fall into contradicting the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). For example, the prohibition of gold and silver: the prohibition came from the Wise Lawgiver with an explicit text regarding men. What is the cause (*Illah*) for that? No textual cause came from the Prophet, but the cause was deduced and differed according to the understanding of the scholars. Some said the cause for prohibiting gold and silver is people's need for the two currencies (gold and silver); if men used gold ornaments in their dress and used it in their eating and drinking, people would lack the two currencies. Some scholars said this. If this cause were conceded, it cannot be said in our time that this is the cause for which the Prophet prohibited it, for in our time people do not need the two currencies (gold/silver) for transactions (buying and selling). The ruling revolves with the cause in existence and non-existence; so would it be said here that wearing gold and eating/drinking from it is permissible for men? Undoubtedly, this cannot be said. Thus, the corruption of the Deduced Cause purported by those who said the Prophet prohibited gold/silver vessels due to the need for currency becomes known. This is known by the passage of time or changing of eras, and it also differs from Imam to Imam.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: What should be known here is that regarding texts coming from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), one must submit to what the Prophet said. If scholars deduce a cause from his sayings of permission or prohibition, they deduce it to explain the wisdom that came from the Prophet for peace of mind, and that he does not legislate except what contains benefit for people and does not forbid except what contains harm, so people know the wisdom of the Wise Lawgiver. However, analogy is not made upon it, nor is it asserted that this cause is definitely what the Prophet intended unless the cause is textual or clearly apparent due to an indication. The Wise Lawgiver may issue many commands and prohibitions where the cause is hidden. If it is textual, no one has a say. The cause is textual from the Prophet regarding the cat: 'of those who go around.' But if it is deduced, no one has the right to draw analogy upon it for other things. Many of the people of opinion became corrupt only due to their analogies in this chapter of types of causes. Regarding the cat and what is in its ruling, the Prophet stated the cause explicitly: 'It is only one of those who go around (*Tawwafeen*) among you.' *Tawwaf* (one who goes around) is one who frequently enters and exits, goes and comes, morning and evening; such is called 'of the Tawwafeen' and 'Tawaf'. Tawaf is called Tawaf due to the frequency of going and coming in it.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Also, linguistically, the Sa'i (striving) between Safa and Marwa is called 'Tawaf'. It came in some wordings of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the Salaf that Sa'i between Safa and Marwa is called Tawaf because there is going and coming in it. Similarly, the Prophet's application of this cause and his textual statement of it allows analogy for this cause to what is in the ruling of the cat among animals 'who go around', like donkeys, mules, and other animals like horses and the like which are a matter of widespread hardship. Since the Prophet stated this cause textually, there is no harm in analogy in such a case. 12- From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A Bedouin came and urinated in a corner of the mosque. The people shouted at him, but the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade them. When he finished his urination, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered a bucket of water and it was poured over it. Agreed upon. This hadith was narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim from multiple paths, including from Hammad from Thabit from Anas bin Malik. This hadith is one of the important ones in the chapter of Purification. Anas' saying: 'A Bedouin (*A'rabi*) came': An A'rabi is one who dwells in the desert (*Badia*), whether Arab or non-Arab. Even a desert dweller who is non-Arab is called A'rabi. The word A'rabi has no singular form from its own root; rather scholars distinguish between plural and singular by adding the relativity *Ya* at the end, so *A'rab* is said for plural and *A'rabi* with the *Ya* for singular. His saying: 'A Bedouin came and urinated in a corner of the mosque': Urine is one of the excretions from the two passages and is impure by consensus of scholars; there is no disagreement in that. Urinating in the mosque is forbidden by consensus. However, scholars differed regarding urinating in the mosque in a vessel: if a person has a vessel while in the mosque, is he permitted to urinate in it?

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The majority of scholars held that it is forbidden. This is a view of the Hanbalis, and the school of the Hanafis, Malikis, and a view of the Shafi'is. Some Shafi'is went to the permissibility of urinating in a vessel in the mosque, saying that the prohibition from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came regarding urinating on the ground of the mosque, but urinating in a vessel is fine. They drew analogy to many things, such as the Prophet's cupping in the mosque—though the report of the Prophet cupping in the mosque is not authentic—and they also used as evidence Sa'd bin Mu'adh staying overnight, as the Prophet set up a tent for him in the mosque. This contains no proof because there is no text stating that Sa'd bin Mu'adh urinated in a vessel in the mosque. The mosque remains upon its sanctity, so it is forbidden to urinate in it. Muslim narrated in this report from Ikrimah bin Ammar from Ishaq from Anas that the Prophet called the Bedouin after his urination and said to him: 'These mosques are not suitable for any of this urine or filth; rather, they are for the remembrance of Allah.' This indicates the purification of mosques from urine absolutely, whether on its ground or in a vessel on its ground. Furthermore, the Lawgiver forbade approaching the mosque with the smell of onions and garlic, so how about the smell of urine? Scholars also differed regarding things other than urine in the mosque, such as passing wind: is it permissible to pass wind in the mosque voluntarily or not? The majority of scholars went to the view that it is not permissible, and whoever needs to pass wind should go outside the mosque. Some scholars permitted it because no evidence prohibiting it came from the Prophet, and the default is permissibility. Those who forbade it said: The ruling of the mosque's space and air is like the ruling of its ground; hence the Prophet forbade entering the mosque for one who ate garlic or onions and similar offensive smells, and this is an analogy to that, so it is *a fortiori*. His saying here: '(The Mosque)':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: The Mosque here: is what is built and its land endowed (Waqf) to Allah Almighty for prayer. As for what is not endowed for prayer, like a building and the like that is not permanent, it is not called a Masjid but rather a Musalla (prayer place) and does not have the rulings of a Masjid like Tahiyyat al-Masjid etc. Regarding urination, it is forbidden to urinate whether in a Musalla or a Masjid because it is a place for prayer. His saying here: '(The people shouted at him)': *Zajr* is scolding and driving away. The Prophet did not forbid their forbidding him, but forbade their *scolding* (shouting/driving away). This is from wisdom in Dawah and the good character the Prophet was granted, for which Allah praised His Prophet saying: {And indeed, you are of a great moral character}. This is one of the instances of wisdom in calling to Allah. The Prophet prioritized a lesser harm over a greater harm. This Bedouin came to the Prophet, perhaps new to Islam; scolding him might drive him away from Islam. Also, the Bedouin had urinated and the urine was flowing; if he were made to move, the urine would spread. The Prophet forbade them and they left him until he finished his need so the urine wouldn't spread. This is the Prophet's wisdom and his consideration of both ends and means. ... A man's urine, whether in the mosque or elsewhere, is purified by water by pouring abundant water over it, as in this report. Some scholars held that the place of urine should be dug up and thrown away, then a bucket of water added. They used as evidence a weak hadith narrated from the Prophet, which Abu Dawud narrated from Jarir bin Hazim from Abd al-Malik bin Umayr from Abdullah bin Ma'qil from the Prophet. It is a report that is not authentic; Imam Ahmad said of it: 'This is a rejected (Munkar) hadith.' Also, Ibn Ma'qil did not meet the Prophet, as Abu Dawud said. Al-Daraqutni narrated this report in his Sunan from another path.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Removing the soil upon which the Bedouin urinated is not authentic from the Prophet. Rather, the correct view is pouring water over the urine without removing the soil the man urinated on. This indicates that water purifies impurity by abundance; hence the Prophet ordered a *Dhanub* (bucket) of water to be poured over it. *Dhanub*: is a large bucket, called Dhanub due to its large size. The amount of water poured should be proportionate to the urine; if it is little, a little water more than the urine is poured, and the impurity of the urine is removed. 13- From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Two dead things and two bloods have been made lawful for us. As for the two dead things: they are locusts and fish. As for the two bloods: they are the spleen and the liver.' Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Majah, and it contains weakness. This hadith was narrated by Imam Ahmad, Ibn Majah, and others from the hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Zayd bin Aslam from his father Zayd bin Aslam from Abdullah bin Umar. It is defective due to Abdur-Rahman bin Zayd bin Aslam, who is weak according to the generality of scholars. Imam Ahmad, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ali bin Al-Madini, Yahya bin Ma'in, and others declared him weak. Abu Hatim asked Imam Ahmad about the sons of Zayd bin Aslam, 'Which is dearest to you?' He said: 'Usamah.' Then who? He said: 'Abdullah.' Then he mentioned Abdur-Rahman and lay down [indicating weakness] regarding Abdur-Rahman. Abdur-Rahman bin Zayd bin Aslam, the narrator of this report in Imam Ahmad and Ibn Majah, is weak according to the generality of scholars. Ibn Ma'in said of him: 'He is nothing.' Abu Dawud said: 'The sons of Zayd bin Aslam are all weak.' The sons of Zayd bin Aslam are Abdur-Rahman, Abdullah, and Usamah, sons of Zayd bin Aslam, freed slave of Umar bin Al-Khattab. Abdur-Rahman bin Zayd bin Aslam and his brothers were solitary in narrating this report as *Marfu'* (attributed to the Prophet), i.e., with a chain to him.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Al-Daraqutni, Ibn Adi, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Ismail bin Abi Owais from Abdur-Rahman, Abdullah, and Usamah from Zayd bin Aslam from Abdullah bin Umar from the Prophet as *Musnad* (connected chain). This is the path of Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Adi. Al-Daraqutni mentioned only Abdullah and Abdur-Rahman. The sons of Zayd bin Aslam were solitary in this report, and they are weak, and it contradicts trustworthy narrators. It came as *Mawquf* (halted at the Companion) from Abdullah bin Umar from the hadith of Abdullah bin Wahb from Sulayman bin Bilal from Zayd bin Aslam from Abdullah bin Umar as his own statement. This is the correct view preferred by the Hafiz scholars; Abu Hatim, Al-Daraqutni, Abu Zur'ah, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Hakim, and among later scholars Hafiz Ibn Al-Qayyim preferred the *Waqf* (attribution to Companion). However, it has the ruling of *Raf'* (attribution to Prophet). Al-Bayhaqi stated that it has the ruling of *Musnad* from the Prophet, because if a Companion says 'It was made lawful for us' or 'We were commanded' or 'We were forbidden' regarding matters specific to the Wise Lawgiver, then it has the ruling of *Raf'*. If it concerns matters not exclusive to the Lawgiver, there is difference of opinion mentioned by scholars of Usul. However, the correct view is that if a Companion says 'We were commanded' or 'We were forbidden', it is raised to the Prophet unless there is an indication implying otherwise, such as a late Companion, or the command being indicated by other narrations to be from one of the Caliphs, or the command not having a textual basis from the Lawgiver, etc.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This report has the ruling of *Raf'* (attributed to the Prophet) in terms of ruling, but in terms of narration, it is not authentic as *Musnad* from the Prophet. Although it appeared in Hafiz Ibn Adi's work from Yahya bin Hassan from Sulayman bin Bilal from Zayd bin Aslam from Abdullah bin Umar from the Prophet, and Yahya bin Hassan followed the sons of Zayd bin Aslam as a partial corroboration, yet he contradicted Hafiz Abdullah bin Wahb, who is one of Imam Malik's companions and a great Hafiz and trustworthy narrator. Abdullah bin Wahb's narration is undoubtedly firmer and more correct due to his majesty and memory, and such weak narrators cannot stand against him. His saying 'Have been made lawful for us': 'Ahillat' is taken from Halal, meaning permissibility. Making lawful and unlawful is the exclusive right of the Wise Lawgiver. No one has the right to permit or forbid except the Wise Lawgiver. His saying 'Two dead things': The singular is 'Maytah'. There are two dialects: *Mayt* with a sukun on the Ya, and *Mayyit* with a shaddah. For what has certainly died, both are permissible. For what has not yet died, the Ya is stressed (*Mayyit*). Some said the two words are equal. Someone recited: 'O asker about the explanation of Mayt and Mayyit / Here I explain what you ask about / Whatever has a soul is Mayyit / And Mayt is only what is carried to the grave.' The default for dead animals (*Maytah*) is prohibition if it is a land animal. As for sea animals, the default is permissibility. The Prophet pointed to this in this report by saying 'Have been made lawful for us' if authentic as *Marfu'*, or from Abdullah bin Umar's statement as *Mawquf*. His saying 'Two dead things and two bloods have been made lawful for us':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This indicates that the default is prohibition regarding carrion. The carrion prohibited by Allah is land carrion absolutely, while He permitted sea carrion absolutely. The two types exempted by Allah from carrion are sea carrion—we discussed this in the hadith of Abu Hurairah, the first hadith in Bulugh Al-Maram: 'Its water is purifying and its dead are lawful.' We discussed the scholars' difference in detail and established that sea carrion is lawful according to the majority. Exceptions have no evidence and remain on the default: either it is sea carrion, so it is lawful, or land carrion, so it is unlawful. What is between them (amphibious) remains on its default of permissibility; if it is repulsive it is forbidden for repulsiveness, if it has fangs it is forbidden because it is a fanged beast prohibited by the Prophet. The Second Type of Carrion: (Locusts). This is by consensus of scholars. No dissenter is known except Al-Layth bin Sa'd and Ibn Al-Arabi (a later scholar). Al-Layth held it to be forbidden, a very strange view; I know of no one who agreed with him, and such an odd view does not befit his standing in knowledge. Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in a book on Al-Layth's biography called *Al-Rahmah Al-Ghaythiyyah bi Al-Tarjamah Al-Laythiyyah*: 'I have tracked books of difference much and did not find a single issue where Al-Layth was solitary against the Imams of the Sahabah and Tabi'in except this issue.' Ibn Al-Arabi said: 'Locusts of Hijaz are lawful and locusts of Andalusia are unlawful,' which is very strange. This view contradicts the consensus; locusts are one, and their permissibility is absolute from the Lawgiver. His saying 'And two bloods were made lawful': 'Daman' (two bloods), singular 'Dam'. The intent here is: An animal with flowing blood, not the blood flowing in veins.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: It is known that beasts either have flowing blood, like livestock, or do not have flowing blood, like insects etc. His saying 'Two bloods were made lawful for us' mentions the first type: (The Liver), which is lawful by consensus without disagreement. (And the Spleen), likewise, scholars have agreed on its permissibility without known disagreement. ******************************* 14- From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'If a fly falls into the vessel of one of you, let him dip it all in, then throw it away, for in one of its wings is a disease and in the other is a cure.' Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Abu Dawud, who added: 'And it protects itself with the wing containing the disease.' This hadith was narrated by Al-Bukhari, saying: Qutaybah bin Saeed told us, Ismail bin Ja'far told us, from Utbah bin Muslim, from Ubayd bin Hunayn, from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His saying in this hadith 'If a fly (*Dhubab*) falls': *Dhubab* is singular, plural *Dhibban*. Common people say *Dhubab* for plural and *Dhubabah* for singular; this is contrary [to standard], though ancient. Abu Hatim Al-Sijistani narrated this variance. The correct view is that *Dhubab* is singular and *Dhibban* is plural; some said the opposite. *Dhubabah* is not eloquent. Ibn Battal and others said it is called *Dhubab* because it wavers (*yadhubb*) over food then returns to it; it wavers due to its filthiness. The fly is not impure (*Najas*). Scholars have agreed that whatever does not have flowing blood does not make liquid or food impure if it falls into it. No one disagreed except a narration reported by Al-Rabi' bin Sulayman Al-Muradi from Al-Shafi'i that if an insect without flowing blood falls into drink or food, it makes it impure. But consensus was narrated contrary to that: that whatever has no flowing blood does not make what it falls into impure, and the default is its purity.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: From creatures without flowing blood, the Lawgiver specified the fly here with a ruling: If it falls into the drink of one of you—and in a narration 'vessel', and in another outside the Sahih 'food'—'drink' does not just mean liquid but encompasses food and all drinks and edibles. This is because the reasoning in the hadith includes both, as the Prophet said 'for in one of its wings is a disease and in the other is a cure' (or remedy). This covers falling into liquid or food. His saying 'If a fly falls into the drink of one of you, let him dip it': Dipping here is obligatory. This is the apparent meaning of the text: one must dip the fly. The Prophet reasoned with a textual cause: 'for in one of its wings is a disease and in the other is a remedy.' This is knowledge of the Unseen revealed by Allah to His Prophet. When a fly falls into a vessel, it falls first on the wing with the disease to preserve the wing with the remedy for the rest of its life. If not dipped, [the disease remains]. If dipped, it usually dies, so its wing with the remedy is dipped, treating this with that, and no disease deposited by the fly remains. Scholars divided animals into two types: First: What has flowing blood. Meaning blood that runs in veins. Its dead body is impure by consensus; details will come in the chapter of Foods.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Second: What does not have flowing blood: meaning no blood in its veins, like insects (flies, bees, locusts, etc.). If it dies, its dead body is pure. For what has no flowing blood does not putrefy nor emit an impure, foul smell upon death, unlike what has flowing blood, which putrefies and has a foul, rotten smell. Hence the Lawgiver forbade eating the latter and clarified it is impure because it becomes impure and putrid due to the trapped blood not being shed. Thus, the wisdom derived by the Prophet is known: If a fly falls into a vessel, dip it then throw it away. If it were entirely impure, the Prophet would not have ordered dipping it but would have ordered removing it. Some scholars said: If a fly falls into a vessel not containing liquid, it is dipped and the food around it removed. There is no evidence for this, and it contradicts the apparent text. It is similar to the hadith of the Bedouin urinating in the mosque; despite the urine, the Prophet ordered pouring water over it and did not order removing the soil. This report is similar; one must stop at the text. Since the Prophet informed that the fly has disease in one wing and cure in the other and ordered dipping it completely, this command must be obeyed. Some ignorant people who turned away from Allah's religion, like modern Mu'tazilah and others, attacked this report and attacked Abu Hurairah's hadith. This is due to their ignorance, for Abu Hurairah was not solitary in this. It came from Abu Saeed Al-Khudri as narrated by Al-Nasa'i and others from Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Saeed bin Khalid from Abu Salamah from Abu Saeed Al-Khudri from the Prophet, and some scholars authenticated it.

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: It was also narrated from Anas bin Malik. There is no room to attack any Companion regarding this hadith if he was solitary, so how about when a group narrated it? Abu Rayyah attacked this in his book *Lights on the Sunnah*, and the scholar Abdur-Rahman bin Yahya Al-Mu'allimi refuted him in his book *Al-Anwar Al-Kashifah*. He refuted him with scientific principles from the Sharia, stating that the Prophet's Companions are all trustworthy and just by Allah's accreditation, and that this is revelation from Allah to His Prophet. There is no room for the intellect to choose what it wants from Allah's revelation and reject what it wants. The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Abu Dawud added: 'And it protects itself with the wing containing the disease.' This addition was narrated by Imam Ahmad and via him Abu Dawud. Abu Dawud said: Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, from Bishr bin Al-Mufaddal, from Muhammad bin Ajlan, from Saeed Al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurairah. Ibn Hibban narrated it via his sheikh Ibn Khuzaymah from Bishr with it. Saeed Al-Maqburi is a famous narrator. This path is good (*Hasan*) due to the status of Muhammad bin Ajlan, for his hadiths are upright and considered Hasan. Saeed Al-Maqburi was named Al-Maqburi because he lived in a graveyard, it is said. They said Arabs used to live near graves. It was said: In the home of every man or family, there was a grave for their dead in their courtyard. The poet says: 'Every people has a grave in their courtyard / They decrease while graves increase.' Hence he was named Al-Maqburi. He narrates from Abu Hurairah, and the Group narrated from him. His saying here 'It protects itself with the wing containing the disease':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: This is from the knowledge of Allah revealed to His Prophet. The Prophet could not say this on his own accord; human intellect and nature cannot perceive this, especially in the Prophet's era. The Prophet's words, actions, and approvals are legislation and religion, unless evidence indicates he said/did it as a custom of his time or context indicates so without textual stipulation. *********************** 15- From Abu Waqid Al-Laythi, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Whatever is cut from a beast while it is alive is dead (carrion).' Narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi who classified it as Hasan, and the wording is his. This hadith was narrated by Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Al-Jarud in *Al-Muntaqa*, and others from the hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Dinar from Zayd bin Aslam from Ata' bin Yasar from Abu Waqid Al-Laythi from the Prophet. The reason for this report is that when the Prophet came to Medina, he found its people cutting the humps of camels and the fat tails of sheep while they were alive to use the fat. Camel humps and sheep tails grow back if not cut from the root. They were benefiting from that, so the Prophet forbade it and informed that what is severed from the living is dead (carrion). This is compassion and kindness to animals from the Prophet first, and also saving humans from eating carrion. The Prophet's saying here 'What is severed from the beast': The beast (*Bahimah*) here refers to four-legged animals, due to the prevalence of Arab practice at the time. The Prophet specified 'beast' because it usually refers to livestock (camels, cows, sheep), though linguistically *Bahimah* includes all four-legged animals. It is called *Bahimah* because of its unintelligibility (*Ibham*) and lack of speech. ... His saying 'What is severed':

book_title: A Segment of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Tarefe's Explanation of Bulugh Al-Maram, Transcribed by Some Interested Parties
text: Meaning whatever is cut from the beast while it is alive is dead (carrion). This is by consensus of scholars; no one disagreed. However, scholars excepted two cases: First case: Musk of the gazelle. If separated from the gazelle while alive, it is pure and permissible to use by consensus; more than one scholar recounted consensus on this. Second case: What runs away from animals and is hard to restrain. If a camel or she-camel becomes wild and hard to restrain, and they strike it, cutting off its hump or a piece of its leg, etc., then what is cut is considered permissible to eat, provided that if that she-camel or camel is caught, it is slaughtered and not left alive, because what was cut is linked to its origin (the animal). This is also agreed upon by scholars. This is specific to beasts. As for what the Prophet permitted eating its dead body originally, whatever is cut from it is considered pure and not forbidden carrion, like fish. Whatever is cut from a fish while alive and not caught/hunted is considered permissible and pure to eat. Likewise locusts; if something is cut from it while alive and not caught, it is permissible to eat because its dead body is originally permissible, not forbidden. Scholars excepted these cases, and no disagreement is known in this issue. And Allah knows best. The rest of the explanation follows, God willing.
